result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote the conservation and sustainable use of coastal and marine biodiversity in the Caribbean and Pacific regions through the design and implementation of a financially sustainable and well-managed SMPA.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Total area (ha) under protection within the SMPA

actual.comment: In December of 2014 were officially declared two MPA’s the National Natural Park Bahia Portete-Kaurrele which has an extension of 14.080 has (Resolution 2096 of December 19, 2014) and Regional District of integrated management of Tribuga Gulf – out current with an extension of 60.138,6 has (011 agreement of December 18, 2014), for a total of 8’640.487,2 has. Adding the private areas of the areas of the of the Civil society natural reserves (CSNR Sanguare and the Almejal), which are 3.631,4 ha, for a total 8’644.118,6 ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Change in ecological representativeness of key coastal and marine ecosystems in MPAs.

baseline.comment:
Deep-water coral: 1.4%
Mangrove: 33.1%
Seagrass: 25.9%
Coral reef: 96.5%
Beach: 11.6%
Coastal cliff: 29.0%

target.comment:
Deep-water coral: 94%
Mangroves: 33.5%
Seagrass: 28.5%
Coral Reefs: 96,6%
Beach: 14.6 %
Coastal cliff: 31.8%

actual.comment:
Deep corals: 64,4%, the percentage reported is due mainly the declaration of the new MPA in 2012; Currently the data remains the same.
Mangroves: 33,7%, the percentage reported is due mainly to the addition of DRMI Tribugá Cabo Corrientes and PNN Bahía Portete Kaurrele, exceeding the target of 33.5 %.
Seagrass: 27.75%, it has included the PNN Bahia Portete. Extention of seagrasses in the PNN CRSB decreased slightly according to the ecosystems monitoring strategy made in 2012-2013 for 7 MPAs.
Coral reef: 96,5%. Remain the same percentage according to the ecosystems monitoring strategy made in 2012-2013 for 7 MPAs.
Beach: 22,2%: The main increase, is due to the inclusion of the SF Acandi-Playon-Playona (11.298,58 ha) and MPA PNN Tribugá Cabo Corrientes and PNN Bahía Portete – Kaurrele, exceeding the target of 14.6%.
Coastal cliff: 32%: The main increase is the result of inclusion of the MPA PNN Tribugá - Cabo Corrientes.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Change in coverage of key coastal and marine ecosystems within seven (7) MPAs (Gorgona NP, Old Providence-McBean Lagoon NP, Corales del Rosario y San Bernardo NP, Sanquianga NP, BahÃ­a CispatÃ¡ MD, BahÃ­a MÃ¡laga NP, and BahÃ­a Portete - last two will be new areas created during the project).

baseline.comment:
ï€­ Mangrove: 51,275 ha
ï€­ Beach: 37,169 m
ï€­ Coastal cliff: 40,610 m
ï€­ Coral reefs: 19,381 ha
ï€­ Seagrass: 7,692 ha

target.comment:
ï€­ Mangrove: 51,275 ha
ï€­ Beach: 37,169 m
ï€­ Coastal cliff: 40,610 m
ï€­ Coral reefs: 19,381 ha
ï€­ Seagrass: 7,692 ha

actual.comment:
The results demonstrate that in general key ecosystem cover has been maintained, in relation to the reference levels. The project has carried out increasingly detailed measurements with high resolution remote sensing, which has allowed for verification and adjustment of the extent of the ecosystems in the seven MPAs. The updated information is:
Mangrove: 51.902,90 ha
Beach: 49.072,44 m
Coastal cliff: 70.663,36 m
Coral reefs: 21.010,53 ha
Seagrass: 6.426,02 ha
The data remains the same because the change in coverage of key coastal and marine ecosystems realized in 2015 is still in process.
2015 monitoring about change in coverage of key coastal and marine ecosystems will be executed in the second part of the year.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Change in bird species richness in six (6) MPAs.

baseline.comment:
Gorgona NP: 151 species
Bahia Malaga NP: 24 species
Bahia Cispata MD: 296 species
Bahia Portete FFS: 25 species
Old Providence-McBean Lagoon NP: 96 species
Malpelo FFS: 62 species

target.comment:
Gorgona NP: 151 species
Bahia Malaga NP: 24 species
Bahia Cispata MD: 296 species
Bahia Portete FFS: 25 species
Old Providence-McBean Lagoon NP: 96 species
Malpelo FFS: 62 species

actual.comment: Last report shows that the number of bird species has been maintained at six marine protected areas. It is expected to start a monitoring between July and November of 2015 to update information. 6 pilot MPAs will have the indicator report at the end of the year 2015, and I will be held an analysis in context to introduce the advance of this indicator.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Ratio between the tendency of the mean length of catch (MLC) and the mean length at maturity (MLM) for three (3) marine species at three (3) MPAs (Gorgona NP, Bahia Cispata, Old Providence-McBean Lagoon NP)

baseline.comment: Tendency for the reduction of MLC/MLM

target.comment: Tendency for the increase of MLC/MLM

actual.comment: The radio between the tendency of the mean length of catch (MLC) and the mean length at maturity (MLM) for three (3) marine species at three (3) MPAs remains the equal to the data on 2013-2014. Project was signed agreements of fishing in the Gulf Tribugá and the DMI Cispata Bay. PNN incorporate their information on the SIPEIN (fisheries information system) for further testing the indicator, all information is expected to collect and analyze at the end of the 2015 in order to update the indicator.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Increase in financial capacity of the SMPA as measured through the Total Average Score for all MPAs in the UNDP/GEF Financial Scorecard.

baseline.comment:
ï€­ Legal and regulatory framework: 57.7%
ï€­ Business planning: 66.1%
ï€­ Tools for revenue generation: 53.7%
ï€­ Total: 59.2%
Note: Baseline assessment is for the entire NNPS. It will be updated at the start of the project to include only the MPAs.

target.comment:
ï€­ Legal and regulatory framework: 67.7%
ï€­ Business planning: 76.1%
ï€­ Tools for revenue generation: 63.7%
ï€­ Total: 69.2%

actual.comment: The Total Average Score has not been updated. The next calculation shall be measured at the end of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Existence of a national budget for the sustainability of the SMPA and its associated MPAs, in line with their conservation goals.

baseline.comment: No budget specific for the SMPA

target.comment: National budgetary allocation for the SMPA

actual.comment: It is currently being compiled information for the calculation of resources from the national government. This indicator will be ready for the years 2009-2015 in July 2015, with a projection for the next four years.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The SMPA is established and supported by a legal, institutional, and operational framework.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Existence of the SMPA as part of the SINAP.

baseline.comment: No official SMPA

target.comment: The SMPA is legally established

actual.comment:
The SMPA is legally established.
Decree regulating the National Protected Areas System (SINAP - initials in Spanish), includes within it the creation of thematic subsystems that constitute a set of protected areas, social and institutional actors, management tools and instruments for its articulation looking for common conservation objectives and addressing specific logical drive. From there, the support of the SMPA arises from the existing regulatory framework of SINAP. SMPA have legal basis making use of the existing regulatory framework for SINAP. Within this regulation framework, it´s created an organization that seeks to integrate management of the subsystems and for the discussions of policies and regulations of them. The National council for protected areas (CONAP - initials in Spanish) chaired by the Minister of Environment, becomes the stage for generating reflections against the regulatory framework and give recognition to the SMPA through the integration of a delegate for it in the CONAP. Having an action plan for the subsystem, with a coordinating organization and a delegate to the CONAP, will shape the SPMA within the existing regulatory framework and give legal backing to it.
Inclusion of the SMPA as part of this Decree was approved within the Management Response.
The conceptualization of the SMPA in Colombia document was also published. Currently SMPA is articulated with the action plans of the Caribbean and Pacific Regional Protected Areas Systems (SIRAP’s initials in Spanish).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of Regional Action Plans with clearly defined guidelines for MPA management.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: Two (2): Caribbean SIRAP and Pacific SIRAP

actual.comment:
Articulated work with Caribbean and Pacific SIRAP has continued as in the previous period, through participation in the areas of technical and management committees of both SIRAPs.
There is a framework agreement for cooperation signed in September of 2014, between the Colombian Caribbean Protected Areas Regional System (SIRAP) and INVEMAR to join efforts for the implementation of the MPAS on Caribbean SIRAP, through the creation of a coordination instance between the SIRAP and INVEMAR to its consolidation within the framework of the SINAP.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of MPAs within the SMPA.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: Up to 26 MPAs by project end

actual.comment:
31 MPAs by the end of 2014 with in the SMPA. Surpassing the target (Up to 26 MPAs were proposed as a target)
According with the mid term evaluation, the project promote the creation of MPAs and it is very successful in generate institutional awareness for it, in other words, the GEF-SMPA Project put in the national, sub-national and local agendas the marine conservation topics.
30 AMP have been registered on the Colombia Protected Areas National Register (RUNAP initials in Spanish), the "Archipelago del Rosario, San Bernardo e Isla Fuerte Marine Protected Area" it is not even registered.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Total area (ha) of coastal and marine ecosystems within SMPA.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: 8.2 million ha

actual.comment: With the MPAs declared on June 2014 to June 2015 period, the goal of coastal and marine areas within the MPAS established for the project has been exceeded, getting from 0 to 8'640.487,2 ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Change in number of MPAs.

baseline.comment: Twenty-three (23)

target.comment: Twenty-six (26)

actual.comment:
31 MPAs. With the MPAs declared in the period June 2014 to June 2015, the goal of MPAs within the MPAS established for the project has been exceeded, getting from 23 to 31 declared MPA. The last two areas declared within the period are:the National Park Portete Bay (December 2014) and the regional area in northern Chocó (DRMI golfo de Tribugá - Cabo Corrientes in December 2014), with the result of 31 declared MPAs..
They are listed below:
MPAs CONTINENTAL CARIBBEAN:
- SFF Flamingos
- National Park Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta
- National Park Tayrona
- SFF Ciénaga Grande de Santa Marta.
- VP Isla de Salamanca.
- National Park Corales del Rosario and San Bernardo
- SFF Corchal Mono Hernández
- National Park Depth Corals
- SF Acandí, Playón and Playona.
- National Park Bay Portete –Kaurelle
- DMI Bay Cispata
- PNR Mouth of Guacamayas
- DMI Ciénaga de la Caimanera
- DRMI Musichi
- DMI Cove River Black
- PNR wetlands of the Leon River and Suriquí
- The Playona DRMI
- MPA archipelago of the Rosary
- DRMI Blue Lake Manatee.
MPA INSULAR CARIBBEAN
- NNP Old Providence Mc Been Lagoon
- PNR Mangrove Old Point
- PNR Jonny Cay
- DMI AMP Sea Flower
AMP PACIFIC
- PNN Utría
- PNN Sanquianga
- PNN Uramba Bay Malaga
- PNN Gorgona
- SFF Malpelo
- PNR La Sierpe
- DMI La Plata
- DRMI Golfo de Tribuga - Cabo Corrientes

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: The SMPA is supported by a sustainable financial system.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Change in the annual government budgeting for national-level MPAs.

target.comment: $1,611,014/yr (increase of up to 17.8%)

actual.comment: This information is currently being updated. The results of this indicator will be ready and updated for the years 2009 to 2015 and a projection for the next 4 years on July 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Change in the amount of financial resources received annually from non-governmental sources (private sector, NGO funding), including PES schemes.

baseline.comment:
$1,025,497 USD from International Cooperation (2009)
$2,338,659 USD from own revenues (2009); revenues generated by ecotourism are distributed among all PAs of the NNPS.
Note: These values are preliminary and the baseline for this indicator will be updated at the start of the project. Additionally, there was not information available for NGO contributions or for MPAs at the regional level.

target.comment: $4,036,987/yr (increase of up to 20.0%)

actual.comment: An estimate of the financial resources that must be provided by non-governmental organizations is being developed. You will get results for the years 2009 to 2015 and a projection for the next four years, on July 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Change in the financial gap to cover basic MPA management costs and investments.

actual.comment: The calculation is currently developing the financial gap to cover basic costs of management of MPAs and investments; we will get results for the years 2009 to 2015 and a projection for the next four years, on July 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of avoided mangrove deforestation pilot projects.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: One (1) by project end

actual.comment:
One pilot project of avoided mangrove deforestation is taking place in DMI Cispata is very succesful. Their lessons learned allowed to applied the methodology in the Pacific coast (Carbon measurements were made in the plot of Luisico (Malaga Bay) on October 2014 and March 2015).
Socialization to communities of mangrove workers on the Pilot Project REDD+ DMI Cispata, La Balsa and Tinajones was made in order to keep communities informed and to define the next steps for the implementations of the project.
We have been achieved progress in the development of a methodological guide for avoided deforestation projects on mangroves within voluntary carbon strategies, in order to document the experience to other areas in the Neotropic not only as a financial sustainability strategy for the mangrove protected areas but also as a climate change mitigation strategy linked with the conservation processes.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of agreements established with direct beneficiaries of marine conservation and MPA users that contribute to the financial sustainability of the SMPA.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: At least two (2) agreements, one for the Caribbean region and one for the Pacific region

actual.comment:
The first agreement on recreation rates to actors involved in diving activities, culminated with the issuance of the resolution number 031 on January 30, 2014, amending resolution No. 245 of 2012 that regulates the income value of rights to the Park National Natural Corals of the Rosary and San Bernardo. The value of the rights of entry was increased in the PNN taking into account the costs of planning, programming, control and monitoring to meet the object of conservation.
During 2014, an additional charge based on the agreement with tourism operators and supported by economic analyses was implemented for Corales del Rosario and Gorgona protected areas.
On May 2015 a formal document (Resolución) from the National Natural Parks was signed concerning the payment for vessel transit in the MPA. Although a preliminary agreement has been made with DIMAR, a software application and a formal agreement is needed for DIMAR to charge the vessels on a biannual basis, along with other regulatory charges they have.
With respect to fisheries agreements, the Tribugá agreement was signed on 21 April 2015 Cispata agreement will be signed in July.
For the case of the agreement for vessels transit, this instrument is being analyzed in terms of legal feasibility and the final report will be delivered in the third quarter of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of business plans for regional MPAs.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: At least four (4) by project end

actual.comment:
Four business plans, three of them are finalized and one is on-going.
Three business plans have been formulated: a) Business Plan of tourist services in the Tribugá DRMI; (b) business plan for the oyster mangrove in DMI Cispata - San Antero, Córdoba; (C) business plan for PNR Old Point.
On going plan is: Business Plan of tourist guides in the DRMI Caimanera, Sucre.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Enhanced institutional and individual capacity for SMPA management.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of MPA staff and SINA officers and stakeholders (government and non-government) trained in PA management, financial planning, and monitoring techniques.

baseline.comment:
35 staff from existing MPAs
25 decision-makers

target.comment:
72 MPA staff trained by project end
100 SINA officers and stakeholders trained by project end

actual.comment:
98 MPA staff trained until June 2015, surpassing the target level at end of project.
95 SINA officers and stakeholders (environmental authorities, companies in the hydrocarbons sector, PNN, MADS, AUNAP, research institutions and academic sector, among others) trained until June 2015. In the second semester of 2015 will be making the last course of the project for this target people.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of higher education institutions (i.e., ecology programs) that include MPA management as part of their curricula.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: Six (6)

actual.comment:
Six (6) higher education institutions include MPA elective lecture as a part of their curricula in the PhD in Marine Science (DCIM initials in Spanish) from November 2015, in this PhD are involved 6 universities in the country that have programs in marine or coastal topics (National University, UJTL University of Magdalena, Northern University, University of Antioquia, University of Valle)
The project also made the approach with local universities like Technological University of Chocó, specifically with the Director of Agroforestal Engineering programme, to include MPA management module in its curriculum. As the Director of the programme affirmed, the idea is to include MPA management module as an elective lecture for Biology and Agroforestal Engineering. The official letter with the proposal was already send by the SMPA project, still waiting for a response.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of existing and new MPAs with strengthened or new planning and resource use agreements.

baseline.comment: Five (5) existing MPAs with planning and resource use agreements

target.comment: Up to eleven (11) strengthened or new agreements for MPAs

actual.comment:
Until now the project are working in the 8 agreements, 5 from 2013-2014, and there are three (3) additional agreements for MPAs in process in:
- DRMI, Golfo de Tribuga- Cabo Corrientes, is in the process of signing the agreement for the development and monitoring of industrial fishing for deep-water shrimp trawling.
- Fisheries agreement with mesh in the Delta - estuarine system of Cispata, whose signature is expected in July.
- PNN Uramba - Bahía Málaga fisheries agreement: control of the fishing gear and species conservation-oriented object. It is expected by the end of 2015 and to this date we may have the agreement signed by the parties.
The agreements development process is still ongoing.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Colombian and international communities are aware of and support the SMPA.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Changes in behavior and attitudes towards MPAs, measured by an attitude/behavioral scale, contribute to the conservation of coastal and marine biodiversity.

baseline.comment: Behavior and attitude test scores (to be established within first 6 months of project implementation)

target.comment: 10% of increase over the baseline in test result on behavior and attitudes

actual.comment:
The target level at end of project was re-formulated in the Management Response, according to the recommendations of the mid term evaluation (before we have 15%, now is 10% of increase over the baseline in test results).
The operation of the site from social networks (Facebook and Twitter), has been strengthened with the publication of videos, photos, messages and interaction with other networks. With the following statistics: Facebook: 1.971 followers, Twitter: 1,101 followers, YouTube: 576 plays and 3 subscribers and Google +: 7.599 visits; achieving in number of visitors by publication in an average of 13.207 compared with the previous year which was 3500. According to the document of the project, surveys to assess the change in the perception and behavior will be delivered at the in the third quarter of the current year.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of funding proposals leveraged by the Friends of the SMPA Society.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: At least five (5) proposals by project end

actual.comment: The call for financial support for the network “friends of the SAMP” is now open to 5 productive projects or business ideas related to the MPA, this is a funding strategy that will support the financial sustainability of the MPAS, as well as the promotion of increase the Friends of the SMPA Society, and generate additional financial resources by the in-kind or cash counterpart by each proponent because for apply to the call it requires at least 40% of counterpart.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of awareness programs undertaken.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: One (1)

actual.comment: “Voices of the sea awareness campaign Black Theatre” was made in the MPA National Park Corales del Rosario and San Bernardo, with intervention on the beaches of San Antero, Coveñas, Mucura Island, Timtipan island and Tolu during June 11 to 15. The campaign delivered messages to encourage tourism, responsible consumption with the sea and its MPs. This managed a range of 3,000 visitors in the beaches, and additionally this event was published live on social networks making a number of visits (scope) of 2.519 and being published in regional and national media.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Percentage of the Colombian population aware of the existence and importance of the SMPA and that fully supports it.

actual.comment:
The target level at end of project was re-formulated in the Management Response, according to the recommendations of the mid term evaluation (before we have 20%, now is 2% Colombian population aware of the existence and importance of the SMPA and that fully supports it).
The implementation of awareness-raising program and the different campaigns in the media and social networks of the project will be help with this goal. This percentage will be evaluated with the surveys in the third quarter of the year.
Participation with a project stand and many conferences at the COLACMAR-SENALMAR XVI (Latin American Congress on Marine Science and Technology and National Seminar on Science and Technology of the Sea) that will be held in Santa Marta, as well as the participation in the International MPA or Protected Areas Conferences will be very helpful for dissemination of the results of the project.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce CO2 emissions through the implementation of a (mandatory) energy efficiency standards and labels program

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: a) Change in annual sales towards average higher efficiency appliances (lower unit energy consumption, UEC)

baseline.comment: According to unit energy consumption (UEC) table in Prodoc

target.comment: Reduction in average UEC (see table in Prodoc) of selected household appliances (refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers and freezers, lamps, ballasts, water heaters, air conditioning equipment, and washing machines) and electric motors

actual.comment: According to the Ministry of Mines and Energy, the Regulations will be issued during 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: b) Share of non-compliant products in mandatory S&L

baseline.comment: N/A (there is no mandatory S&L)

target.comment: Measured as part of surveys of component 2 at the end of the project

actual.comment: The issuance of the Technical Regulations (RETIQ) on standardization and labelling for energy end-use equipment has been delayed for reasons beyond the control of the project and the executing agency, preventing us from measuring the progress on this indicator. This indicator shall be measured at the end of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: c) Energy consumption trend

baseline.comment: Annual energy demand will increase to about 80 TWh by 2020

target.comment:
With URE (Government\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\'s policy on rational use of energy), annual power demand in Colombia is expected to stabilize at around 50 TWh, implying savings of 30 TWh, out of which 6.7 TWh of savings can be attributed to the use of more EE appliances.
Of the 6.7 TWh savings, 60% (4 TWh) is expected due to the direct and indirect impact of this project ´s intervention

actual.comment: UPME performs an energy balance every year in various sectors. The adjusted figure for energy consumption was 57,614 GWh in 2013. Residential 21,293 GWh, industrial 19,685 GWh, commercial 14,830 GWh, and other 1,806. The energy balance will not be the only tool used to monitor this indicator; it shall be supplemented by a strategy to measure the specific impact of equipment labelling. However, it is important to note that equipment labelling has no impact on the country's energy consumption as the Technical Regulations are yet to be issued. This indicator will be monitored once the Technical Regulations are released.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: d) Amount of CO2 avoided (in comparison with baseline level)

baseline.comment: CO2 emissions will rise in accordance with energy consumption (see project objective indicator c)

target.comment:
Direct emissions reduction (cumulative over period 2011-2015):1,309 ktCO2
Indirect emissions reduction (cumulative 2016-2025): 9,511 ktCO2
Annual energy savings due to EE appliances 11.4 TWh 2025 (of which 60% can be attributed to the project)

actual.comment: The estimate for total reduction by the year 2025 is about 4 million tons of CO2, which amounts to 66% of total emissions due to energy consumption in the residential and commercial sectors in Colombia. This reduction, which corresponds to nearly 2% of the total emissions of the energy industry according to the National Emissions Inventory (INGEI), will be mainly achieved through the implementation of the Regulations in commercial and domestic refrigeration equipment, gas heaters, gas appliances, and air conditioning equipment. This baseline is defined in the study that the project conducted during the reporting period, "Current Market Structure" (May 2015). This evaluation established that the implementation of the RETIQ brings an environmental benefit to society and promotes the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the period defined by the study, 2015-2025, compared to a scenario without RETIQ. This reduction is mainly due to the energy consumption related to energy end-use equipment.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced capacities of key public and private agencies

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: e) Status of programs in key public agencies to implement effective mandatory S&L

baseline.comment: Insufficient implementation of S&L program which is voluntary only

target.comment: New policy provisions and compliance checking, enforcement and outreach programs adopted for mandatory S&L that reflect international € œbest practices

actual.comment:
This project contributed to the implementation of energy efficiency measures, identified through 19 regional workshops (163 people) and 2 virtual workshops (53 people), amounting to a total of 216 officials trained during this year, giving a boost to the growth of the institutional capacity to meet the labelling requirements once the Regulations come into effect. Moreover, the training modules that were carried out as part of the project (February 2015) have been included by the SENA, as a strategic ally, as inputs for the curricular design of the training course “Energy Efficiency Labelling." The modules have been very important for training and will continue to take place throughout 2015-2016. Additionally, the project made a diagnosis of the National Quality Subsystem (SNCA), the instance for promoting markets through quality and productivity, by coordinating activities between public and private organizations for the standardization, technical regulations, accreditation, compliance and metrology assessment. In this way, we identified the strengths and weaknesses of these organizations for the implementation of the Regulations. The suggested Regulations were disclosed in 2 meetings with the SNCA entities, with the attendance of 28 public officials. There was an assessment on the capacity of the country's laboratories to meet the demand for testing once the Regulations are issued, concluding that the country has a group of laboratories competent enough in the short-term to carry out energy efficiency tests on refrigerators (7 laboratories) and gas appliances (7 laboratories). Currently, there are not any laboratories that can perform tests on washing machines, but it was found that there are 2 laboratories with a high potential for carrying out the aforementioned tests or trials in the short-term. As for air conditioners, there is only one laboratory with a high potential for carrying out the tests. These conclusions, and other related to the demand for future testing once the Regulations are issued, are included in the study, which significantly contributed to the strategic lines in order to strengthen not only the network of laboratories in the country, but also the SNCA as a whole.
These results were made public through 3 workshops for 107 people. Additionally, the project took part in the World Metrology Day with a presentation about Labelling Regulations and their relationship with the SNCA and metrology (May 20th 2015). 50 people attended this workshop.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Consolidated information on the market structure and established market transformation strategy with defined instruments and procedures

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: f) Level of information available to define energy consumption in label categories and for measuring project impact

baseline.comment: Data available at UPME\'s database, but needs to be updated and expanded (CM: YA SE TIENE LA LINEA BASE?)

target.comment: Upgraded database and regularly updated data on annual sale of different appliances per energy classes (A to G) available for public use (with finalized market monitoring methodology)

actual.comment: The information on the structure of the national market for equipment subject to the RETIQ project was updated and consolidated. There was also an assessment of the behaviour of the market in the face of the inclusion of mandatory labelling of energy efficiency parameters (May 2015). The study considered variables such as existing equipment and equipment currently being used in Colombian households, replaced equipment, produced equipment, imported equipment, exported equipment, equipment sales, annual energy consumption associated to existing equipment, equipment prices. Thus, the National Government has a diagnosis of the current market and its analysis on projected sales through a model that determined the impact the RETIQ would have if it comes into effect. This study has made a great contribution to the country by providing a current picture of market behaviour and an in-depth analysis on the areas that must be strengthened in order to achieve a positive transformation of the market, where energy efficiency is considered as a variable in purchasing decisions. One of the main conclusions of the study is the need to work and direct efforts toward training the sales force, who directly influence purchasing decisions of Colombian consumers. Their current training and information level is very poor; there is work being done alongside the industry (ANDI) to start providing this training to the sales staff of companies.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: g) Status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability (transformation strategy)

baseline.comment: S&L system in place is voluntary, but has limited impact so far

target.comment: Market transformation strategy enhanced for implementation of mandatory S&L (programs, procedures and organizational arrangements, including testing and enforcement) with a budgeted implementation plan

actual.comment: There have been 12 inter-institutional meetings (Ministry of Commerce, Ministry of Environment, Superintendence of Industry and Commerce, SENA, Confecámaras, ANDI, FENALCO, Asodelco, ANDESCO, ACAIRE, Corpotrece). Additionally, there was 1 workshop to disclose the results of the study on the current market for equipment (37 participants). The purpose of this workshop was to follow up on the commitment of public and private authorities regarding the implementation of the Regulations as part of a comprehensive strategy for institutional sustainability. As a result of these meetings, each entity took ownership of the labelling process and a communication strategy for Labelling in Colombia was established, bringing together the efforts made by various public and private entities on the subject.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Strengthened legal framework for mandatory S&L and endorsed final Technical Regulations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: h) Status of decision-making regarding introduction of mandatory EE S&L

baseline.comment: Mandatory MEPS exist for CFLs; voluntary labels and MEPS for ballasts, cloth washers, fluorescent lamps, refrigerators and freezers, air conditioners and electric water heaters

target.comment: Decree(s) signed on Technical regulations making labels (and/or MEPs) mandatory for electric motors and household appliances (in the following order of priority: refrigerators and freezers, lighting, ballasts, room air conditioners, water heaters and washing machines)

actual.comment: Institutional strengthening, the issuance of the regulations, and the support to their implementation are sustainability standards. As a result, the Ministry of Mines and Energy, the Ministry of Commerce, and the Ministry of Environment are committed and will work together so that both the Technical Regulations and the associated processes are established as a national guideline for disseminating this policy.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Consumer and industry engagement strategy developed and implemented

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: i) Priority of different criteria used by customers in their purchasing decision

baseline.comment: No emphasis among the consumers (and sales personnel) on energy efficiency aspects and life cycle costs when purchasing and marketing new appliances

target.comment: Beside the initial purchasing price, energy efficiency and life-cycle costs have become a key criteria for purchasing decisions, guided by the energy label

actual.comment: The project still has its web page (currently at www.etiquetaenergetica.gov.co, now integrated to UPME's server) with the purpose of providing information related to the energy label. The web page is expected to help end consumers understand how their purchasing decisions influence energy consumption and climate change. The page also contains, with access to the general public, Training Modules (4 Modules), an educational and learning support material developed by the project (February 2015). These modules also serve as input for SENA in formulating curricular plans for nationwide implementation through on-site or online courses The web page currently shows an increase of 73% in the number of new users. Moreover, the project designed a communication strategy to support the dissemination and promotion of labelling, which included the participation of 14 strategic allies. This strategy cross-sectionally supports every component of the project in order to establish mutually beneficial relations with public and private actors, toward the dissemination of information regarding labelling. This is done by providing new communication settings and channels, different from those obtained through procurement, as well as generating public opinion and a discussion on the subject of the project, and gathering materials or contents that support or reinforce the messages already designed. In this way, the strategic allies (ANDI, FENALCO, Ministry of Commerce, Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Mines and Energy, Confecámaras, Andesco, Asodelco, Corpotrece, SENA, SIC, ONAC, INM, ICONTEC) are committed to supporting the activities for training, dissemination, advertising, and generation of content through their own channels. This aims at the appropriation and adequate response to the matter from a communication approach that can have regional and national impact.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Monitoring and evaluation the for project and EE S&L program carried out

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: j) The level of information available for monitoring and evaluation and adaptive management

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment: Adequate information available for monitoring & evaluation and for measuring project results

actual.comment: The project has an operating and decision-making structure that allows us to disseminate information and results through different means. Decision-making tasks are the responsibility of the Steering Committee, which meets twice a year (11.26.14 – 05.19.15) to discuss and approve project activities. Additionally, a follow-up meeting is held quarterly with UNDP and the executing agency. This allows continuous monitoring of project activities. In addition, the project Coordination Unit carries out a daily follow-up of all activities. This year, the first Project Financial Audit (February 2015) took place, which resulted in a Low Risk Rating, given that the project management has properly strengthened its administrative procedures, processes, and policies.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To protect human health and the environment locally as well as globally arising from unsound PCB management in Colombia

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Quantity of PCBs (liquids and solids) destroyed in the project period (2013-2017).

baseline.comment: 1000 MT PCBs destroyed pre- project through exports.

target.comment: Additional minimum of 600 MT of PCBs (liquids and solids) disposed of in an environmentally sound manner.

actual.comment: To this date the project has resulted in the elimination of 451.1 MT (75.2% of the target). Of this quantity, during the 2014-2015 reporting period 104.1 MT was exported for disposal. In addition, during this reporting period 47 MT of non porous solid waste contaminated with PCBs were treated by using washing processes.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Quantity (tonnes) of equipment and waste contaminated by PCBs, that is stockpiled by the year immediately preceding the closure of the Colombia PCB inventory.

baseline.comment: 400 MT PCB stockpiled

target.comment: All known PCBs safely stockpiled.

actual.comment: According to national inventory reports, 585 MT of waste was stored. From the total, 534,3 MT of waste are in the owners and 50,8 in authorized facilities.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Persons from environmental, health, and comercial authorities, trained and qualified in PCB management.

baseline.comment: Environmental, health and commerce authorities personnel do not have the knowledge and training to execute control and monitoring of the PCB stockpiles in the country.

target.comment: 50 officials of the environmental, health and commerce authorities trained to control the commerce, storage, transport, treatment and final disposal of PCBs.

actual.comment:
Of a total of 13 workshops held since the project’s start, 6 workshops were held during the reporting period 2014 to 2015 during which 6 environmental authorities and 5 foreign trade authorities were trained.
Of a total of 210 cumulative participants, 93 participants were trained during the current reporting period.
This number of participants is equal to 4 times the project target.
Training workshops addressed technical aspects and regulations on storage, transportation and proper PCB environmental disposal.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: One (1) norm elaborated for thermal treatment

baseline.comment: Since 2013, the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development is elaborating a norm which regulates the thermal treatment of dangerous waste and requires that specific studies be elaborated to establish the treatment of other waste that is considered extremely toxic such as PCBs.

target.comment: One (1) norm approved for thermal treatment.

actual.comment: A draft of the regulation of thermal treatment of hazardous waste was developed for the Ministry of Environment, whom should include in its text PCB burn tests results.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of guidelines / manuals established for PCB management.

baseline.comment: In 2011, Colombia released the Resolution 222, through which the management and PCB elimination goals are managed in accordance to the requirements. This norm requires that PCB owners, and equipment which contains PCBs that is in use or disuse, be marked. Different methodologies have been developed at the national level to carry out PCB equipment marking, and these methodologies must be compiled into a report. The norm establishes measures for the adequate maintenance of the equipment and the avoidance of cross-contamination.

target.comment: 4 guidelines / manuals developed by end of the project

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: The indicator will measure how many demonstration projects have been developed within the project framework to treat or eliminate equipment and waste with PCBs in Colombia.

baseline.comment: The country has no facilities for treatment or disposal of PCBs.

target.comment: At least two treatment and disposal alternatives in demonstrative pilot projects servicing PCB owners.

actual.comment:
In December 2014 the pilot project of installation and operation of the washing plant for equipment contaminated with PCB was completed. The project was funded through a Partnership Agreement signed between project and LITO S.A.S.
9 units contaminated with PCB with concentrations ranging from 58 ppm to 85.000 ppm PCB were washed.
In addition, as part of the agreements signed between the project and CEMEX COLOMBIA S.A and TECNIAMSA S.A., evaluations and ratings were completed and were selected the best two (2) facilities to conduct PCB burn tests, one test burn for each company.
Industrial safety evaluations were conducted to prepare test protocols and a company was hired to prepare the strategic communication management process to communities located near CEMEX facilities.
During the period 2014-2015 the project prepared a project to finance the installation of a facility at semi-industrial scale for demonstrating the elimination of PCB.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of companies implementing new regulatory guidelines

baseline.comment: A new PCB management base regulation has been passed. No new guidelines PCB holders or service providers are in compliance with new guidelines

target.comment: 15 maintenance companies operating according to new guidelines.

actual.comment:
As of June 30, 2015 a document summarizing best practices for maintenance activities, is available.
It includes an assessment of the operations and good practices from 20 companies (133% of the project target).
All 20 companies participated in the preparation of these documents.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of operators, technicians, and professionals trained in the adequate management of PCBs.

baseline.comment: Training and capacity building is required for personnel who work for businesses involved in PCB management and for those in the electricity sector who have waste equipment with PCBs, so that they may carry out their work in accordance with national and international standards.

target.comment: 50 maintenance and other personnel at PCB holders trained in safe PCB handling.

actual.comment: During the second half of 2015, under the framework of GRANT with CIDET, three (3) validation workshops related to the compilation of good maintenance practices were held, 70 people attended these workshops representing about 20 companies engaged in these activities.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Number of businesses that provide transportation, storage, or elimination of PCBs in accordance with national and international standards.

baseline.comment: Currently there are six businesses in the country who provide storage and transportation services for PCBs; there are none who carry out PCB elimination. The businesses involved with PCB elimination must comply with national norms and international standards.

target.comment: 6 Service providers (storage, packing and transport) operating according to new guidelines.

actual.comment:
Three (3) service providers have been evaluated against the standards for storage, packaging and transport of PCBs.
Currently only one (1) company has three (3) secure warehouses that can operate according to standards.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthening the legal, administrative and regulatory framework for the sound management of PCBs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: A norm for dangerous waste management which includes PCB treatment.

baseline.comment:
There has been a new regulation (Resolution 222) for the PCB Management in Colombia that needs to be implemented.
There is not a norm that regulates the treatment and elimination of PCB wastes.

target.comment: A legally binding norm or technical regulation for the treatment of PCBs issued.

actual.comment:
A draft of amendment of the PCBs regulation (Resolution 222) was formulated and put into public consultation during this reporting period.
The Ministry of Environment continues, by consulting national and international experts, the process of issuing the Regulation for Thermal Treatment of Hazardous Waste.
The Ministry will incorporate the results of the PCB burn tests, in particular technical and safety requirements.
This regulation is expected to be completed and in public consult by 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Personnel from the environmental, health and customs authorities are trained for the implementation of the existing norms issued for PCB management, including controlling PCBs in body fluids and food and import control system for electrical equipment (transformers, capacitors) and dielectric oils

baseline.comment: The Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development in December 2011, issued a guideline on the management of PCBs, which has established a number of responsibilities for generators of this waste.

target.comment: Eight workshops or training sessions with officials from the environmental authorities to present the existing norm and the norm or regulation for PCB treatment.

actual.comment:
Up to June 20, 2015 11 workshops only for environmental authorities were conducted (137% of the target), 4 were held during 2014-2015 period (24 officials of environmental authorities were trained during the current reporting period).
The workshops included the main aspects of the regulations governing the management of PCB (Resolution 222 of 2011).
It is expected that through this training approach, authorities will become aware of the technical and management aspects involved in PCB management.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Guidelines or a document which orient the work of health authorities in controlling population exposure to PCBs.

baseline.comment: The health authorities have no programme established to evaluate PCB incidence in impacted populations.

target.comment: Guidelines for the health authorities to formulate controls for PCB exposure have been established

actual.comment: As of June 30, 2015 there is a signed agreement with the National Institute of Health (NIH) for the development of epidemiological surveillance protocols and their application during next period (2015- 2016), for a sample group of people potentially exposed to PCB.

baseline.comment: The health authorities have no programme established to evaluate PCB incidence in impacted populations.

target.comment: One workshop with the health authorities related to the human exposure of these substances delivered.

actual.comment: The workshop will be developed by the National Institute of Health (NIH), under the agreement signed during the second half of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Guidelines or a document which orient the work of commerce authorities in the control of importation and exportation of equipment and waste with PCBs.

baseline.comment: There is no existing protocol for the control of importing and exporting of PCB contaminated equipment and waste at the ports and border crossings

target.comment: Guideline or instrument published so that the customs authorities, the police and other commercial authorities can control the importation and exportation of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes.

actual.comment:
A draft document “Guidelines for the Control of Import/Export of PCB contaminated Equipment and Waste” aimed at foreign trade authorities is available. It is currently under going its validation by relevant authorities.
There was also a process with foreign trade authorities for the characterization of control processes implemented the last four years in imports related to transformers that may contain PCB. .

target.comment: Three workshops to present and distribute the guidelines or instrument for the control of imports of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes completed.

actual.comment:
Up to June 30, 2015 there have been two (2) workshops (67% of the goal) aimed at foreign trade authorities, with a total of 89 attendees from six national authorities.
These workshops have included aspects related to the transboundary movement procedures for PCBs (Basel Convention), safety and health aspects in activities related to PCB handling and management alternatives in Colombia.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Economic or financial instrument evaluated for the promotion of PCB management.

baseline.comment:
There are fiscal exceptions for investments in PCB environmentally sound management.
There are credit lines available with non-refundable funding for companies that invest in issues such as quality control and environmental management.

target.comment: Evaluation of feasibility of applying economic, financial or market instruments to promote environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs completed.

actual.comment: 100% of the target was achieved. The final report, analyzing the feasibility and implementation of economic instruments related to PCB management activities, has been published.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Labeling strategy for the identification of PCBs in equipment (in use and out of use) implemented in companies in the electricity sector.

baseline.comment: The Colombian norm for PCB management establishes that the equipment that could have PCBs (transformers and capacitors) should be identified and labeled. Currently only a limited number of equipment have been labeled regarding PCB content.

target.comment: Development of a demonstration project with the equipment owners that have PCBs for the labeling of equipment using the different available alternatives.

actual.comment:
During the reporting period 2014 – 2015, a project for the identification and marking of PCB equipment owned companies that provide services in a not interconnected Zone, was prepared and financed by the project through a GRANT developed by CIDET.
Currently 15 companies in the power sector are working on activities to identify and mark PCB containing equipment.
During the reporting period the project finished a guidance document summarizing available alternatives for marking equipment.

target.comment: All tested equipment should be labeled by the end of the project.

actual.comment: Currently companies from the electric sector are working on equipment marking tasks to meet the requirements of the current regulation, which states that at least 30% of PCB containing equipment should be marked by 2016.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Development of national capacity for environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Information system operating to consolidate, disseminate and update in an orderly and periodic manner the data related to the inventory and management of PCBs in the country.

baseline.comment: The IDEAM has a tool to register and update the inventory of the amount of PCBs eliminated. The PCB generators must keep the information up to date using electronic means.

target.comment: Information platform to manage PCBs established and updated.

actual.comment:
With financial support provided by the project, maintenance and strengthening of the National PCB Inventory and information system continues, lead by IDEAM.
As of April 30, 2015, the PCB information system showed that: 840 owners of equipment and waste are registered and active. These owners have reported about 430.000 pieces of PCB containing equipment containing dielectric oil.
Of these 840 owners, 138 were registered during this reporting period 2014-2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of (public and private) laboratories strengthened for sampling and analysis of PCBs and other persistent pollutants in different matrices (oil, water, soil, air, food, blood and breast milk).

baseline.comment: There are approximately 10 private laboratories that have PCB analysis capacity as well as the laboratories from the Universities and research centers that can be strengthened for PCB analysis (Universidad de Antioquia, Universidad National, Universidad del Valle and the Universidad de Cartagena).

target.comment: A program of technical assistance for 10 laboratories to validate the analytical methods to identify PCBs in different matrices has been developed.

actual.comment:
During the reporting period the project has performed a Intercalibration exercise between national laboratories.
Currently 20 laboratories (200% of the target) have participated in activities of technical assistance funded by the project.

baseline.comment: There are 3 accredited laboratories for measuring of PCBs in water and dielectric oils. There are laboratories that have the equipment to analyze PCBs and some are doing so.

target.comment: An exercise of intercalibration developed with at least 10 private or public laboratories including IDEAM in Colombia, in the issue of PCB quantification in different matrices.

actual.comment:
The intercalibration exercise took place during the period 2014-2015 and included the participation of 20 laboratories (200% of the target). The intercalibration exercise concluded that 18 participating laboratories have a highly satisfactory level to measure PCB in dielectrics oils.
As of June 30, 2015, 8 laboratories are accredited for the determination of PCB in various materials (oil, water, soil), of which 3 received accreditation in the period 2014-2015.

baseline.comment:
There are no laboratories that measure PCBs in body fluids such as blood and maternal milk.
There are no existing official protocols for sampling and analysis of PCB in dielectric oils, water, soils, air, foods and body fluids.

target.comment: One protocol for sampling and analysis of PCBs in dielectric oils, water, soils, air, foods and body fluids developed.

actual.comment: The resolution 792 of 2013 (Por la cual se adoptan los protocolos de muestreo y análisis para la determinación del contenido de PCB en aceites dieléctricos y diferentes matrices ambientales) established the national protocols for the sampling and analysis of PCBs in dielectric oils and other environmental matrixes. It is a national regulation by IDEAM.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: PCBs in high-risk food are monitored.

baseline.comment: The Ministry of Health and Social Protection has plans to issue a norm to regulate food contaminants, which includes to set limits on PCBs.

target.comment: A monitoring program on PCB in high risk food (e.g. fish, milk) has been created.

actual.comment: A draft agreement for the development of a monitoring program for PCB in fish products, between the Ministry of Environment and the National Institute of Food and Drug (INVIMA) was formulated.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Establishment of guidelines and standards for the environmentally sound management of PCBs (oil and contaminated equipment) during maintenance of equipment, transportation, storage and disposal, including occupational health and safety issues published and distributed.

baseline.comment: There is a manual for PCB management, as well as norms that establish the basic principles for proper environmentally sound management.

target.comment: Technical criteria for the maintenance of equipment with dielectric oils established.

actual.comment: There is also an identification and description document of good practices for equipment maintenance, with such document a diagnostic process was developed in 20 companies in the sector. These documents will be included in the Manual for Sound Management of PCBs.

baseline.comment: A new norm is planned to be established for the incinerating of PCBs.

target.comment: The technical aspects that should be considered for the packing and transporting of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes are defined.

actual.comment: The Manual for the Sound Management of PCBs, finalized during this reporting period (2014- 2015), contains a chapter on the technical requirements for storage, packaging and transport of PCBs. The manual is currently under review by the Ministry of Environment before being published.

baseline.comment: There are no technical guidelines for the maintenance of equipment contaminated with PCBs.

target.comment: The following publications (manuals or guidelines) developed by the end of the project:
1. Guidelines for the identifying, labeling and characterization of equipment with PCBs.

actual.comment:
The project target was met.
During this reporting period, a document (Marcado de equipos eléctricos que consisten, contienen o pueden contener PCB y desechos contaminados con PCB) collecting techniques and suppliers for PCB equipment marking and labeling, was issued by the project.

target.comment: 2. Manual for the registering of PCB contaminated equipment and oil stocks, for environmental authorities and PCB generators.

actual.comment: In addition to the document for the validation of PCB inventory information (Guide for validating the quality of information in the PCB Inventory for environmental authorities), during (2014 – 2015) a tool was developed and made available to PCB owners to support the design and planning for strategic random sampling for monitoring equipment.

target.comment: 3. Manual for methods to identify PCBs in soils, water, food and body fluids.

actual.comment: The project target was met during previous reporting period. No further activities to report on.

target.comment: 4. Guidelines for the selecting of PCB treatment and elimination technologies.

actual.comment:
Manual for Sound Management of PCB is under revision due observations from the public (waste managers and PCBs owners) within a public consultation process .
Once finished this Manual will contain a specific chapter on alternative technologies for decontamination and disposal of PCBs in the country.
As of June 30, 2015 the Manual is still under review by the Ministry of Environment.

target.comment: 5. Guidelines for the environmentally sound management of PCB containing equipment (transport, storage, maintenance, operation, and final disposal).

actual.comment: The Manual for Sound Management of PCBs includes a specific chapter on storage, transportation, packaging and disposal of PCBs.

target.comment: The publication of a video on PCB management.

actual.comment: This activity has not begun yet but it has been determined that the preparation and editing of videos of the project will be conducted with the support from the Office of Communications of the Ministry of Environment.

indicator.title: Indicator 16
indicator.description: National training program on the new standards, guidelines and regulations for stakeholders involved in the handling of PCBs (maintenance companies, junk yards and recycling plants, large consumers and industries, retail consumers and industrial users among others).

baseline.comment:
There is not a structured program for the training of personnel who do maintenance on PCB contaminated equipment and their proper management.
The existing norm for PCBs establishes that for the sampling of PCB contaminated oils the personnel should be certified by the National Learning Service (SENA).

target.comment: One program developed for the training and certifying of qualifications for technicians and operations personnel that do sampling of dielectric oils in equipment and also do maintenance.

actual.comment: Up to June 30, 2105 there are a total of 229 SENA certified technicians on sampling for determination of PCB in dielectric oils. of the 229 certified to date, 100 technicians were certified during the period 2014-2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 18
indicator.description: Number of authorized operators for the management of equipment or oils containing PCBs increased.

baseline.comment: Some of the electrical companies have storage capacity for PCB contaminated equipment and oils in an environmentally safe manner, especially those that are the largest generators, commercializers and distributors. There are four companies that have storage capacity for PCB contaminated equipment and oils and which have environmental license from the corresponding authority.

target.comment: An assessment to define the needs for storage, packing and transport of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes carried out.

actual.comment: A report was developed on current storage, packaging and transportation practices for PCBs, identified areas that need strengthening for authorized waste managers.

target.comment: A program is established to strengthen the capacity of managers and environmental authorities to issue the respective environmental licenses and complete the corresponding follow up.

actual.comment: During the reporting period the project collected strengthening needs for waste managers, in order to formulate and implement for them the strengthening program.

indicator.title: Indicator 20
indicator.description: Definition of criteria to identify, prioritize and remove from use equipment located in high risk areas, in accordance with the provisions of the Stockholm Convention.

baseline.comment: There is not a protocol and criteria established for the identifying and defining of priorities for equipment management in high risk areas.

target.comment: Equipment inventory and program for the removal of PCB contaminated equipment from high risk zones has been carried out.

actual.comment:
Up to date, there are 13 companies located in the not Interconnected Zone (NIZ) that have been registered as PCB holders and who are actively participating in the national inventory reporting of 279 units.
An additional 9 companies will participate in the NIZ pilot related on marking and identification of equipment under the project GRANT signed during the period 2014-2015 with CIDET.

indicator.title: Indicator 21
indicator.description: PCB contaminated sites identified, guidelines and action plan proposed.

baseline.comment: There is not a protocol and criteria established for the identifying and managing of PCB contaminated sites.

target.comment: Action plan for the environmental authorities to start an identification of contaminated sites program created.

actual.comment: Currently there has been a list compiled of companies and zones that will be prioritized for the identification of contaminated sites by regional environmental authorities.

target.comment: Protocol and criteria developed for identifying and managing PCB contaminated sites.

actual.comment: This activity has not taken place yet. During the first half of 2016 there will be a document that will guide the actions to be taken by the regional environmental authorities for the identification and characterization of PCB contaminated sites.

target.comment: One workshop on the presentation of the action plan with the environmental authorities personnel completed.

actual.comment: According to the schedule of activities defined by the project it is expected that during the second half of 2015 there will be a workshop on the action plan that the environmental authorities must develop for the identification of PCB contaminated sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 24
indicator.description: Other stakeholders besides the electricity sector that have existing stocks of equipment and/or materials contaminated with PCBs with content exceeding 50 ppm have been identified and included in national inventory.

baseline.comment: The Regulation 222 established a series of criteria for the identifying, labeling and characterizing of PCB wastes. There is a PCB generator register which is administered by IDEAM. All generators of PCBs must report their stocks to this entity

target.comment: A demonstration project to identify the different equipment owners of the generation, distribution, commercializing, and distribution energy companies developed.

actual.comment: During the period 2014 - 2015 a pilot project was formulated to educate PCB owners part of the EPSA S.A. E.S.P. company network, located in the municipality of Buenaventura - Valle del Cauca.

indicator.title: Indicator 25
indicator.description: Identification (analysis, inventory) and environmentally sound management of PCBs in Non-Interconnected Areas (ZNI).

baseline.comment: In the areas that are not interconnected (ZNI) to the national electricity network there has not been an inventory done for PCB equipment and oils. Some of these equipments are found in high risk zones (ecological, protected zones, forest reserves or vulnerable populations).

target.comment: Technical Assistance for the energy service providers in the ZNI for the identification of equipment and the compliance with Resolution 0222 of 2011 carried out.

actual.comment:
Up to June 2015, 6 training and activities were held aimed at companies located in the not interconnected zones (NIZ). 2 of these sessions were conducted in the reporting period 2014-2015.
During the period 2014 -2015 a pilot program was formulated on marking and identification of equipment located in the non-interconnected zone.
In December 2015 the implementation of that pilot program will be launched with the participation of 9 companies in the NIZ.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs through demonstration pilot project.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Agreements with PCB holders and/or waste managers to demonstrate the operation, maintenance, disposal and storage of PCBs in accordance with new standards, rules and regulations established.

baseline.comment: During equipment maintenance (transformers) cross contamination can occur.

target.comment: One training program carried out with 15 maintenance companies that work with equipment that has dielectric fluids and company personnel in the electricity sector so that they are made aware of the criteria established in the Resolution 222 of 2011. This will avoid cross contamination and implement environmentally sound management of PCBs.

actual.comment: The draft guide for good practices in maintenance is being validated by a technical committee made up of delegates from seven companies.

baseline.comment:
It has been identified that companies that do equipment maintenance in some cases do not have sound management practice for PCB waste
There are six companies in the country that have environmental license for PCB storage, but it has been detected that they do not manage the oils contaminated with PCBs correctly.
The environmental authorities do not have the technical tools that will allow for control and monitoring of companies that have these practices.

target.comment: Technical assistance program developed with six companies that service storage, packing, and transport (land and ocean) PCB contaminated equipment and oils so that these activities are completed considering the best available technology and the best environmental practices.

actual.comment:
The Manual for Sound Management of PCBs was developed during the period 2014-2015 and includes a chapter on storage, packaging and transport of PCB, in line with BEP/BAT requirements.
A report on the strengthening of needs identified for a sample of 13 companies, managers and transporters, has also been prepared during this reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Partnering with interested technology servicers to evaluate alternatives for the decontamination and disposal of equipment and oils contaminated by PCBs.

baseline.comment: The country has two companies that have environmental license to manage PCBs, one for re-cleaning and the other for dechlorination with sodium. There is also a company that has three rotary incinerators for hazardous waste and where there is presently a project pilot for the eliminating of ODS. This company has declared interest in doing a pilot project for PCB elimination.

target.comment: Partnerships established with at least two interested technology servicers to evaluate alternatives for the decontamination and disposal of equipment and oils contaminated by PCBs, through the following pilot projects:

baseline.comment: There are 4 companies that export PCBs.

target.comment: Pilot project for the implementation of decontamination technologies for PCB contaminated equipment and to establish environmental requirements for the control and monitoring by the environmental authorities.

actual.comment:
During the period 2014-2015 the equipment washing pilot project was completed with LITO S.A.S.
9 pieces of waste equipment were decontaminated. It was cleaned a total of 47 MT of non-porous material (metal) and it was destined for metal recycling facilities.

target.comment: Pilot project to develop testing of PCB elimination through thermal processes (rotary kiln or coprocessing in cement kiln), in order to establish the operating conditions for the use of this treatment.

actual.comment:
During the period 2014-2015 technical and environmental assessments were carried out to select the two plants that will perform tests burn for PCB in order to determine the feasibility of using these technologies in the country.
The selected plants underwent an evaluation on to assess safety and occupational health issues.
Under the agreement signed with CEMEX, was selected a company specialized in strategic communications to design and implement a communication plan of the pilot.
A group of national and international experts is available for the design, implementation, analysis and consolidation of results.

target.comment: Pilot project for the treatment of PCBs using dechlorination, plasma, catalytic oxidation or other technology.

actual.comment:
During the period 2014-2015 the project for the installation of a semi-industrial scale plant for the disposal of PCB by oxidation was formulated.
The project will be developed by Universidad del Valle.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Management and disposal of as much of the PCB contaminated equipment as possible that is located in high priority areas identified in the country.

baseline.comment: The electrical service companies that are in the non connected zones in many cases are located in zones that are vulnerable from the ecological and social point of view.

target.comment: PCB contaminated equipment located in the Non-Interconnected Areas that are considered to be high environmental and ecological sensitivity removed and eliminated.

actual.comment: During the period 2014-2015 the terms of reference for the bidding process of removal and disposal of PCB equipment were prepared.

baseline.comment: It has been identified that in zones that are high priority ecological reserves in the Choco or the Amazonia there are PCB contaminated equipment that have been abandoned and the oil has leaked onto the soil.

target.comment: 600 tonnes PCB contaminated equipment and oils from the ZNI or from the owners in high ecological interest zones or high social vulnerability zones eliminated.

actual.comment:
Currently a total of 404.1 MT of waste contaminated with PCB was exported in compliance with the formalities of the Basel Convention.
During the period 2014-2015 a Project on the identification and marking of equipment located in a non-interconnected zone was formulated, the project will determine the amount of waste and equipment to be eliminated in NIZ and the process of removal and disposal is expected to be developed during 2016.

baseline.comment: Measurements of PCBs in breast milk and body fluid have not taken place because measurements are still required to determine whether the population that is potentially exposed presents any contamination levels.

target.comment: Tests of PCBs in body fluids (blood and breast milk) carried out with a group of people who have been or are exposed to PCBs in a region or activity that is considered to be of high impact and establish a protocol for its national application by health authorities.

actual.comment:
An agreement was prepared and signed with INS, which includes the development of a monitoring program for PCB in human milk and body fluids.
According to the schedule of agreed upon activities, sampling and analysis will take place during the period 2015-2016.

baseline.comment: One business in the electricity sector has identified a PCB contaminated site and is aware of a site located in the Department of ChocÃ³ that is contaminated by PCB.

target.comment: Monitoring of PCBs in potentially contaminated soils in a site or region that is of high priority.

actual.comment:
Two sites potentially contaminated with PCB were identified during this reporting period.
Guidelines of PCB contaminated sites identification for environmental authorities are currently under development.
Monitoring of these sites will be conducted once the guidelines have been finished .

target.comment: Identification and testing of abandoned equipment.

actual.comment: Abandoned electrical equipment has been reported in the municipality of Lloro - Choco . Using the project resources, the equipment will be analyzed (weight and PCB concentration) and be removed from the area and taken for proper environmental disposal.

indicator.title: Indicator 14
indicator.description: Technical and environmental feasibility for each one of the technological alternatives proved and the lessons learned for their replication.

baseline.comment: The demonstrative pilot projects will have the involvement of the environmental authorities, PCB generators, treatment companies in order to guarantee that the projects can be replicated.

target.comment: Technical and environmental evaluation for each of the proven alternatives, establishing lessons learned and their publication.

actual.comment: The final report for washing waste equipment is ready. For the other demonstration projects the final results will be incorporated in the same report, including lessons learned and opportunities for replication.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Monitoring, adaptive feedback, outreach and evaluation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

baseline.comment: No documents in baseline situation.

target.comment: 4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year

actual.comment: Quarterly reports were submitted to UNDP accordance with the requirements of the institution.

target.comment: 1 annual APR/PIR submitted to UNDP each year.

actual.comment: The second annual report of the project will be presented this year.

target.comment: 1 Mid-term evaluation.

actual.comment: UNDP developed the terms of reference for the mid-term evaluation and int. bidding is on-going. The MTE will take place during the second half of 2015.

target.comment: 1 Final evaluation

actual.comment: The final evaluation will take place in 2017, when completing the project.

target.comment: MTE and FE must include a lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results.

actual.comment: Communication and support material was shared in events, including notebooks, flyers and banners.
