result.title: Objective
result.description: To prepare a Third National Communication document and present it to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and to the country, with coherent, transparent flexible and comparable information, considering the national circumstances of Colombia.

baseline.comment: The project counts with information generated by the First and Second National Communications and by the vulnerability and adaptation projects implemented so far.

target.comment: As a non-Annex I party, Colombia seeks to share information on its GHG emissions for the years 2005, 2008 and 2010, report on the national policies to face GHG emissions, and adaptation measures to climate change adverse effects; capacity building and public awareness activities; and produce information on the country’s vulnerability to climate change and extreme weather events, to allow the country to prepare to face the impacts of climate change. This information shall reflect the limitations, problems and obstacles found in the implementation of the UNFCCC.

actual.comment:
The Third National Communication on Climate Change project has the following consolidated progress to date:
1. New climate change scenarios for Colombia 2011-2100, as generated at the regional and departmental levels.
2. Results for the four sectors of the National Greenhouse Gasses Inventory of - 1990-2012 series (technical documents, worksheets and reporting tables).
3. Overview of mitigation actions implemented at the national level.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: National Circumstances, updated national development priorities in the context of climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National Circumstances, updated national development priorities in the context of climate change.

baseline.comment:
The project counts with information on:
a) political and geographic aspects; b) environmental offer; c) social characteristics; d) economic characteristics; e) planning and policy actions related to climate change as of year 2010.

target.comment: The goal for this component is to update information for the period 2008-2014 on institutional, ecosystem, social, economic and political issues. The analysis will be made for the national and regional contexts. There will be a close look at the marine and coastal areas and the national circumstances related to extreme weather events will be described. A national and regional analysis on the national priorities for the country’s National Development Plan will be presented.

actual.comment: With regard to national circumstances, progress has been with the issuance of the document on national circumstances that have given way to institutional and territorial vulnerability to the effects of climate change and greenhouse gases emissions in the country.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: National GHG inventory for the years 2005, 2008 and 2010

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National GHG inventory for the years 2005, 2008 and 2010

baseline.comment: The project counts with information on GHG inventories for 1990, 1994, 2000, and 2004. The component includes five modules as determined by the 1996 IPCC guidelines: 1) Energy; 2) Industrial Processes; 3) Agriculture; 4) Land use, land use change and forestry; and 5) waste.

target.comment: The goal is to calculate the GHG inventories for the years 2005, 2008, and 2010, according to the 2006 IPCC guidelines. A database will also be developed with information for each module and emission factors used.

actual.comment: Substantial progress has been made in this regard, as documentation has been generated and is currently available – including technical documents, worksheets and reporting tables for the 1990-2012 series of the National Greenhouse Gases Inventory. The National GHG Inventory estimated emissions by sources and removals by sinks of greenhouse gases based on the methodologies expounded in the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for the main sectors: Energy, Waste, Industrial Processes and Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use. The inventory results – in all sectors – have been validated through workshops and inter-agency working groups. In addition, quality assurance reviews have been held with international experts for some of the sectors. Data are currently being consolidated and integrated for the whole series calculated.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: National and sectorial mitigation measures compiled and evaluated in the context of the Colombian Low Carbon Development Strategy

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Report of information about the actions to mitigate climate change in Colombia.

baseline.comment: The project counts with information on national plans and policies related to climate change and Colombia’s participation in Clean Development Mechanisms.

target.comment: The goal is to report the mitigation actions taken by the country, in regard to the implementation of the Colombian Low Carbon Development Strategy -CLCDS. In addition there will be a description of Colombia's participation in international carbon markets, and the development of National Appropriate Mitigation Actions - NAMAs. Finally, the progress of the REDD Strategy will be reported.

actual.comment: Progress on the issue of mitigation measures is included in the document of mitigation actions carried out by Colombia. The latter document reports the developments attained by these actions in the country, thereby delving into issues such as the Colombian Low Carbon Development Strategy, which covers the Sectorial Action Plans and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions, the Strategy for Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation, Colombia's participation in carbon markets, and addresses the issue of voluntary commitment on mitigation actions under the Cancun agreements.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Sectorial and regional vulnerability to climate change in Colombia, evaluated according to improved methodologies

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Vulnerability to climate change in Colombia, evaluated according to improved methodologies.

baseline.comment: The country counts with a methodology developed by the SNC for climate change vulnerability analysis. There are climate change scenarios available, as a tool for vulnerability analyses. The project counts with the compilation of results of the various vulnerability and adaptation projects.

target.comment: The TCN seeks to generate updated climate change scenarios for the period 2011-2100. Identify current and projected threats under climate change. Analyze the vulnerability to climate change with a better resolution for the natural regions of Colombia, and for water resources, glaciers and the health sector. Additionally, identify the vulnerability to climate variability and extreme events.

actual.comment:
As for the issue of regional and sectorial vulnerability to climate change, significant progress has been made including the preparation and publication of new climate change scenarios for Colombia 2011-2100. These scenarios were generated both regionally and by departments, taking into account variables of precipitation and average temperature, and following the methodologies proposed by the IPCC. The new scenarios of climate change have been widely disseminated through printed media, digital apps, posts on IDEAM and UNDP websites, and holding events (including transmission via streaming), meetings and press releases.
In addition, an analysis was conducted on the annual series for the 1981-2100 period of the multi-scenario assembly for precipitation and temperature variables, in order to represent them spatially.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Other information and knowledge relevant for compliance with the UNFCCC objectives

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Other information and knowledge relevant for compliance with the UNFCCC objectives

baseline.comment: During the SNC a strategy on education, training and public awareness on climate change was initiated. The project counts with information on the results of this strategy. Also the project counts with additional information related to technology and financial needs for the achievement of the UNFCCC objectives.

target.comment: The goal is to include additional information related to actions that the country has taken on climate change. The results obtained in the strategy on education, training and public awareness on climate change will be included, at the national, regional and sectorial levels. A summary of the country’s technology needs for adaptation and mitigation, which includes the progress on the Technology Needs Assessment (TNA).

actual.comment:
With regard to other relevant information and knowledge for the fulfillment of the objectives of the UNFCCC in Colombia, progress has been made in the analysis of financing issues, through the progress document which includes information about Colombia’s sources, obstacles and needs in relation to funding for climate change actions, which includes global experiences on issues of financing for climate change, international methodological routes for the analysis of funding sources, and issues related to identification of (international national and regional) funding sources, investment and resources available for climate change funding in the country.
Progress has also been made in the field of education, through the result analysis report in the implementation of the National Strategy for Education, Training and Public Awareness on climate change, which involves some of the work currently under way in conjunction with regional nodes of climate change, through workshops and surveys.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To apply the Nagoya Protocol provisions on access and benefit-sharing through the development of nature-based products, benefit-sharing and biodiversity in the Chocó region of Colombia

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of hectares of forests in the Chocó bioregion under sustainable management due to the proper use of Genipa americana for the production of a dye

baseline.comment: 400 ha

target.comment: 500 ha

actual.comment:
400 ha. The initiative currently harvests jagua in the area where Cocomacia, the owner of the biological resource, has an environmental permit from Corpouraba. With support from the project Cocomacia has been able to submit to Corpourabá two reports about the way it is implementing the corresponding managament plan which is supervised by Corpourabá. Cocomacia however is still lacking an additional environmental permit to be able to harvest jagua in Chocó. This permit was requested by Cocomacia in 2012, but Codechocó, the corresponding environmental authority, hasn't yet answered this petition. We are working to understand and rectify this situation so the permit is finally granted. The Ministry of the Environment is following up on Codechocó because they need to give an answer; but this is not very likely and beyond project control.
Through the project we expect to increase this baseline by 100ha; mainly by increasing purchases and sustainable management in the area where Cocomacia already has an environmental permit (Corpourabá's permit allows Cocomacia to harvest fruit in 500Ha). However, we would still fall short on the target level by 250ha. In order to achieve this, one of two things would need to happen: a) Codechocó grants the environmental permit, or b) we seek to increase the area of the permit granted by Corpourabá. The first option is highly unlikely, the second is not desirable at the moment, since harvests are still way below the volumes granted by Corpourabá in the current permit. Because of this, the Directive Committee of the project determined that we will not be able to meet the 750Ha target, and has agreed to set the new target at 500ha of forests under sustainable management at the end of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Monetary and non-monetary benefits received by the State and local communities and derived from commercialization of the dye

baseline.comment:
Monetary: a) State: $0; b) communities: $0
Non-monetary: a) State: there are no non-monetary benefits; b) communities: 26.47% of agreements fulfilled

target.comment:
Monetary:
a) State: 0 COP.
b) Communities: 13,120,000 COP/month
Non-monetary:
a) State: socialization of good practices with Corpourabá, Codechocó and IIAP and institutional strengthening of communities and associations that are providing the biological resource
b) communities: 100% of agreements fulfilled

actual.comment:
The Access to Genetic Resources for commercial purposes contract was signed by the Ministry of the Enviornment and Ecoflora in December 2014. This contains the monetary and non-monetary benefits that Ecoflora must share with the State. An ancillary contract was signed between Ecoflora and Cocomacia (representing the community) on March 2013; this gives Ecoflora access to the biological resource that is owned by Cocomacia.
Monetary:
a) State: 0 COP (in compliance with the negotiation between Ecoflora and Colombia's Ministry of the Environment in December 2014, in which the State gave Ecoflora a 4-year grace period to start paying it a royalty; thus Ecoflora will begin to pay Monetary benefits to the State in 2018).
b) Communities: 3.802.697 COP/month (project average: 49.435.059 COP/13 months - we exclude December and January from the denominator because jagua purchases do not occur during those months). Monetary benefits received by communities include the money producers receive for selling their jagua and the money that is being paid to community members related to the collection of the fruit (wages paid to the crew that collects the fruit, rental of equipment and payments for associated services). Several factors are affecting this target: a) jagua supply and demand haven't grown as expected because the necessary permits have not been granted yet (permits to collect the fruit and permits to sell the dye); b) tension between the local commercial platform and the company that produces the dye provoked the temporary suspension of the supply of jagua; c) the local commercial platform is not operating, and because of this it is not yet producing profits that could be distributed with producers, the community organization and local investors.
Non-monetary:
a) State: none yet (the negotiation between Ecoflora and Colombia's Ministry of the Environment was finalized in December 2014; these activities are to be carried out by Ecoflora in the second semester of 2015).
b) communities: the parties are complying with 38% of the agreements (these refer to the 34 agreements negotiated during the Consultation process with the community that gave way to the ancillary contract between Ecoflora and Cocomacia). The agreements fall in 6 categories: 1-Training and social programs, 2-Relations with producers and sourcing agreements, 3-Trees management and harvest conditions, 4-Supply contract between Ecoflora and the local commercial platform, 5- Administrative and logistical aspects to strengthen the supply chain, 6-Communication and dissemination of progress in the project. 13 agreements are considered in compliance; responding to relations with producers and sourcing agreements, to maintance and identification of jagua trees, to hiring people to collect the fruits, to having a local non-banking correspondant and to disseminating information about the Consultation process. One agreement to hire people in each community to collect the fruit is not being fullfilled because the volumes of jagua purchases are not high enough. The other 20 agreements are in partial compliance.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Development of natural plant colorants for the food, cosmetics and personal care industries

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Production capacity of powdered dye

baseline.comment: 0.7 ton/year

target.comment: 3 ton/year

actual.comment:
1,5 ton/year
Ecoflora has installed additional equipment, increasing production capacity and optimizing the efficiency of the plant. The development of the production and quality protocols implied analyzing critical points of the transformation process, resulting in an optimization of the latter. In particular, the optimization of the peeling process has considerably increased production efficiency.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Plant with industrial capacity for production of blue dye

actual.comment:
61%
The plant has been enhanced with industrial and laboratory equipment. The first has allowed for increases in the production capacity, and it includes a transporter belt, an industrial food processor, a powder mixer, a cutting machine and an evaporator. The laboratory equipment allows Ecoflora to perform stability and quality tests for the dye, the equipment purchased is a digital refractometre, an agitator, a sterile tap, a microplates reader, a computer, a rotoevaporator, a nitrogen system, an evaporative light, a deuterium lamp, a tungsten lamp, and an espectrofometer.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Strengthening of a value chain involving sustainable and efficient supply and marketing capabilities for natural dyes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Volume of fruit received by ECOFLORA, which complies with the environmental sustainability and quality conditions

baseline.comment:
8 ton, total volume of jagua
(average Dec 2012-Aug 2013)

target.comment: 83 ton, total volume of jagua

actual.comment:
7 ton have been purchased during the 13 months of the project - December and January are not considered because purchases don't take place during these months). The Directive Committee finds it clearer to express this indicator in total volume of jagua instead of an average monthly value; thus the baseline would be 8 ton (considering a 1ton monthly average between December 2012 and August 2013).
Several factors are affecting jagua supply and demand: delays with the permits to collect the fruit and permits to sell the dye, the fact that the local commercial platform is not operating, tension in the commercial relationship between the latter and Ecoflora, a suspension in the production in May and June 2015 due to problems installing a machine in Ecoflora’s plant (the problem is now solved). Because of these reasons, jagua purchases have not been constant: jagua was only purchased in 6 months instead of in 13 months as expected. In those six months, the average monthly purchase has been around 1.2tons of fruit. Additionally, the project intends to increase the production capacity of the dye to 3 tons of dye per year: since the conversion rate of jagua fruit to dye is 5%, this would imply buying 60 tons of jagua fruit in one year, running the plant at full capacity. Thus, Ecoflora will not be able to buy and process 16.4ton of fruit per month (corresponding to 16.4 tonsx10 months=164 tons) as set in this target.
Because of this, the Directive Committee of the project approves to set this target at 83 tons, which corresponds to the sum of the baseline volume of fruit purchased before the project started (9 tons) and the volume of fruit purchased during the project (74 tons distributed in 2014, 2015 and 2016).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Total annual income from jagua fruit producers sold for the production of natural dyes

actual.comment:
3227 USD, using the exchange rate that was used when the project was formulated of 1US$=1800 COP
The price for jagua fruit agreed with producers is being met; however the volumes of purchased fruit are lower than planned. as explained before, there have only been 6 purchases from August 2014 to June 2015 instead of 13 as originally planned (due to difficulties in the commercial relationship, with the local commercial platform and in Ecoflora's plant). Additionally, the volumes of each purchase have not increased significantly because pending permits are hindering supply and demand (one permit to collect the fruit and permits to sell the dye internationally).
Because of this, and because of the change in the previous target, the Directive Committee approves to set the target of total annual income received by jagua fruit producers at 23.945 USD (this includes the income that all jagua producers will receive in the last year of the project).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of producers who benefit from the purchase of the jagua fruit

actual.comment:
55 families (31 families of producers included in the baseline+ 24 new families from which jagua was purchased during the period August 2014-June 2015)
The number of families (producers) that sell jagua to the initiative vary according to the availability of fruit and they tend to increase as the volumes in jagua demand increase (but these haven't increased because of the reasons stated before). Additionally, when the baseline was established, the initiative planned to purchase jagua in Antioquia and Chocó because they had a permit to collect jagua for research purposes in both regions. The volumes authorized by this permit were completed in 2013. Since Cocomacia was granted a permit to collect jagua for commercial purposes in Antioquia, purchases have continued in this territory, but purchases to the families in Chocó have been interrupted because the necessary permit has not been granted.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Volume of blue dye sold under international regulations

target.comment: 3 tons

actual.comment:
0.032 tons
Ecoflora's main target market is in the US and Europe, but they still don't have the FDA and EFSA permits that will allow them to sell the dye in these markets. However, they have been granted the INVIMA permit to sell the dye in Colombia and they are exploring other markets that have less stringent authorization processes to sell the dye. This has allowed them to begin selling the dye before getting the FDA and EFSA permits.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Access and benefit-sharing agreements

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Access to genetic resources for commercial purposes contract signed, which includes an operational benefit-sharing system

actual.comment:
1
The access to genetic resources for commercial purposes contract was signed by Colombia's Ministry of Environment and Ecoflora in December 2014. In it, the parties negotiated the monetary and non-monetary benefits to the State. An ancillary contract was signed between Ecoflora and Cocomacia (representing the community) on March 2013; this gives Ecoflora access to the biological resource that is owned by Cocomacia.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Public presentation of the progress in benefit-sharing and distribution indicators

target.comment: 3 (1 annual)

actual.comment:
1
The annual meeting with communities to present the progress concerning the agreements was held in February 2015 (it was planned for November 2014 but had to be postponed due to security issues in the area). The project coordinator, the local coordinator, a representative of Cocomacia and an Ecoflora representative took part in the activity. This meeting was held in one community and the report was delivered to local actors to be disclosed in other communities.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Increase in national and regional capacity in ABS through negotiating and monitoring benefit-sharing agreements

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Proposal of a decree or resolution to facilitate the negotiation of monetary benefits between the user of genetic resources and the state for ABS agreements with commercial purposes

actual.comment: The proposal of a decree or resolution was initially to be elaborated by a team of experts in ABS during 2014, but the activity was postponed to 2015 because the Ministry of the Environment was waiting to have the results of another consultancy that delivered technical and legal guidelines as an input for this one. The Terms of Reference were shared with short-listed experts and we are waiting for the results of the process to hire the experts.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Capacity of MADS on access to genetic resources and benefit-sharing measured with UNDP’s ABS Capacity Development Scorecard

actual.comment: The activities to develop capacities related to access to genetic resources in entities of the Environmental National System (SINA) are programmed for 2016, once we have the proposal of a decree or resolution to facilitate the negotiation of monetary benefits between the user of genetic resources and the state for ABS agreements with commercial purposes. In the meantime, we are cooperating with another GEF project (conservation in areas affected by mining) and MADS to arrange a meeting with regional environmental authorities to explore the difficulties in issuing permits for the use of non-timber natural resources (this is the permit that Codechocó has not given Cocomacia). The meeting is planned for the 24th of July (confirmation by the regional environmental authorities is pending).

result.title: Objective
result.description: To safeguard biodiversity in the Chocó biogeographic region from the direct impacts of gold, silver and platinum mining and indirect impacts of mining [population growth and development of agriculture, forestry, fisheries and other sectors]

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Four (4) Existent protected areas (PA) under sustainable management protecting local ecosystems

actual.comment:
47,811 ha
5 work agreements have been signed for the implementation of activities with 4 National Natural Parks (Orquideas: Asociación Colombiana de Acuicultores; Tatamá: Corpocam and Asocasan; Farallones: Amatea; Munchique: Corpohabitats) to improve their sustainable management through monitoring, control and surveillance in Tatamá NP (37.811 ha) and Farallones NP (10.000 ha)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Total area of protected forests (ha) by new multiple use protected areas (MUPA,) created to reduce the impacts of mining

actual.comment:
An analysis of the document "Conservation priorities for the Chocó ecoregion" was held, including extra criteria to select new protected areas initiatives, such as: Being part of the temporary reserve of natural resources, have mining pressures in the zone, include indigenous communities on its buffer zone and to be a conservation priority for the Regional System of Protected Areas from the Pacific (RSPAP). Through this analysis, two (2) initiatives were selected to promote their declaration process: Páramo del Duende and Bosques del Citará (Upper part of the Atrato basin).
There is an agreement with the "Constructores de Paz" foundation to support the regional environmental authority (Codechoco) in the process of declaring the multiple use protected area (MUPA) of “Cuenca alta del río Atrato” in the department of Chocó.
Through this agreement, a work plan will be set and other activities are going to be held such as the design and delimitation of the PA and the generation of the final protocol to conclude with the formal creation.
In addition, processes of creation of new protected areas have been identified in the Cauca and Nariño departments, that are included in the Choco ecoregion

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Management effectiveness change on four (4) protected areas according with the effectiveness scorecard

baseline.comment:
? Orquídeas NNP 67
? Tatamá NNP 43
? Farallones NNP 53
? Munchique NNP 70

target.comment:
- Las Orquídeas NPP : 87
- Tatamá NPP: 63
- Farallones de Cali NPP: 73
- Munchique NPP: 80

actual.comment: There was a review of the management effectiveness assessments of the 4 protected areas. Methodology and dates of new applications were set to use the information in the updating of the METT score

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: The Policy, legal and planning framework in the mining sector addresses the direct threats to biodiversity from mining operations.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Legal, political and planning tools (of national level) include environmental and social criteria to prevent/mitigate, offset and restore the impacts of mining on biodiversity and ecosystem services

baseline.comment: Legal, political and planning existing tools:a) Mining code, b) Required environmental license for the exploitation phase c) Frame for environmental impact assessment

target.comment: Updated tools (legal, political and planning) with recommendations to include environmental and social criteria to prevent/mitigate, offset and restore the impacts of mining on biodiversity and ecosystem services; a) Mining code, b) Environmental licensing process, c) Guidelines for designating areas in the mining reserve.

actual.comment:
Contributions and advice given by WWF in the design of the Strategic Environmental Assessment methodology for the mining sector, on the meeting facilitated by the Planning National Department (NPD)
A document-mapping was constructed to identify different mining-environmental political, normative, and regulatory tools
A document-mapping and analysis of stakeholders was constructed(Public and private organizations, Civil organizations, communities, etc.) related with mining activity in the Pacific Region.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of entities of the mining and environmental sector integrated to a main information platform for decision taking.

target.comment: Environmental sector: 5 (Parques Nacionales, IIAP, ANLA, Codechoco, Corpourabá ) Mining sector: 1 (ANM)

actual.comment:
Baseline updated from the different information systems of the mining and environmental sectors . In addition, the project was socialized and information sharing agreements were proposed with:
- Ministry of environment and sustainable development (MADS)
- Ministry of mining and energy (MME)
- Environmental research institute for the Pacific region(IIAP)
- National Parks Agency (PNN)
- Regional authority for sustainable development in the Choco department (Codechocó)
- Regional authority for sustainable development in the Uraba region (Corpourabá)
- The National Authority for Environmental licensing (ANLA)
- Hydrology, meteorology and environmental studies Institute (IDEAM)
- United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC Colombia)

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Protection of biodiversity in areas highly vulnerable to the indirect effects of mining.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of municipal planning instruments (POT) that includes the priority zones for conservation, and zoning to deal with direct and indirect impacts of mining on biodiversity and ecosystem services

actual.comment:
A general information analysis was held for the environmental, biodiversity, ecosystem services, and environmental determinants components of the Territorial Zoning Plans (POT) in the municipalities of Murindó, Vigia del Fuerte, Tado and Buenaventura. In the 9 prioritized municipalities, the advances of the POMCAS were revised.
It was formulated an agreement with the IIAP to advance in the inclusion on the POT of biodiversity protection tools against mining, in the municipalities of Tado and Vigia del Fuerte. Additionally, through this agreement, the identification of direct and indirect impacts of mining and its relationship to ecosystem services in these two municipalities will be held.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Change in the capacity to generate, use and share geographic, socio-economic and bio-physical information necessary for territory planning and management that take into account the indirect impacts of mining according to the UNDP Card Capacity Development
(200 people trained: Regional environmental authority Officials, National Parks Agency Staff, officials of municipalities, community organizations members)
to. Capabilities involvement
b. Capacity to generate, manage and use information and knowledge
c. Capabilities for designing strategies, policies and regulations
d. Management and implementation capabilities
e. Monitoring and evaluation capabilities
(200 personas entrenadas: Funcionarios CARs coordinadores a nivel nacional de AP, Funcionarios de los municipios, entes de control y Ministerio Publico y Personas de las organizaciones comunitarias)
a. Capacidades de involucramiento
b. Capacidades de generar, gestionar y utilizar información y conocimiento
c. Capacidades para el diseño de estrategias, políticas y normatividad
d. Capacidades de gerencia e implementación
e. Capacidades de monitoreo y evaluación

target.comment:
Total people trained: 200
Local level
Capacity / Espavé / Asocasan / Cocomacia
a 2,40 / 2,20 / 1,60
b 1,60 / 2,10 / 1,00
c 0,90 / 1,65 / 0,90
d 1,20 / 1,20 / 1,20
e 1,20 / 1,60 / 1,60
Regional level
Capacity / IIAP / Codechocó / PNN Munchique / PNN Farallones / PNN Orquideas
A 2,40 / 2,00 / 2,80 / 3,20 / 2,40
B 1,80 / 2,60 / 1,00 / 1,00 / 1,60
C 2,10 / 1,20 / 0,90 / 1,20 / 1,80
D 1,60 / 1,60 / 0,80 / 0,80 / 1,60
E 2,00 / 2,40 /1,20 / 2,00 / 2,40
National level
Capacity / ANLA / ANM / MME / MADS
A 2,00 / 1,60 / 2,40 / 3,00
B 1,20 / 2,00 / 2,40 / 1,80
C 1,50 / 1,80 / 2,10 / 0,90
D 0,80 / 0,80 / 2,40 / 1,20
E 0,80 / 1,60 / 2,40 / 2,00
Goal: 20% increased based on the current capacity

actual.comment:
A baseline was established as input for the training capacity building plan of the project. Issues such as training offer in the project area were analyzed, and also in other cities (Bogotá and Cali). Information was gathered on training needs for institutions and communities around the topics of the project . Interviews were made with entities such as the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development (MADS), Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME),the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Alexander von Humboldt Institute (IAvH), Institute of Environmental Investigations of the Pacific (IIAP), Codechocó, Bioinnova, ASOCASAN, Cocomacia and the Universities of Los Andes, Javeriana and Claretian.
A document with the available technical training offer was prepared, identifying possible partners in Universities and academic sector. The information was arranged in a matrix detailing demand information by theme and target audience.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Area (ha) of land degradated by mining under short and medium term restoration processes (protocol) in key biodiversity areas

target.comment: 100 ha

actual.comment: An agreement with the Institute of Environmental Investigations of the Pacific (IIAP) was established to implement the ecological restoration protocol at the Choco region, starting with the identification of the areas to be intervened. The diagnosis of at least 200 hectares identified for restoration will take place, local capacity to implement the methodology of the protocol will be analyzed and preliminary analysis of socio-environmental viability of the areas identified restoration will take place.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of new Multiple Use Protected Areas (MUPA) created

actual.comment:
An analysis of the document "Conservation priorities for the Chocó ecoregion" was held, including extra criteria to select new protected areas initiatives, such as: Being part of the temporary reserve of natural resources, have mining pressures in the zone, include indigenous communities on its buffer zone and to be a conservation priority for the Regional System of Protected Areas from the Pacific (RSPAP). Through this analysis, two (2) initiatives were selected to promote their declaration process: Páramo del Duende and Bosques del Citará (Upper part of the Atrato basin).
There is an agreement with the "Constructores de Paz" foundation to support the regional environmental authority (Codechoco) in the process of declaring the multiple use protected area (MUPA) of “Cuenca alta del río Atrato” in the department of Chocó.
Through this agreement, a work plan will be set and other activities are going to be held such as the design and delimitation of the PA and the generation of the final protocol to conclude with the formal creation.
In addition, processes of creation of new protected areas have been identified in the Cauca and Nariño departments, that are included in the Choco ecoregion

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Four (4) protected areas increase control and surveillance capacity / Measured by METT

baseline.comment:
PNN Las Orquídeas: 2 - Protection systems are moderately effective in controlling the use of access / resource
PNN Tatamá: 1 - Protection systems are only partially effective in controlling access using / resource
PNN Farallones de Cali: 1 - Protection systems are only partially effective in controlling access using / resource
PNN Munchique: 2 - Protection systems are moderately effective in controlling the use of access / resource

target.comment:
PNN Las Orquídeas: 3 - Protection systems are largely or wholly effective in controlling the use of access / resource
PNN Tatamá: 3 - Protection systems are largely or wholly effective in controlling the use of access / resource
PNN Farallones de Cali: 3 - Protection systems are largely or wholly effective in controlling the use of access / resource
PNN Munchique: 3 - Protection systems are largely or wholly effective in controlling the use of access / resource

actual.comment:
5 work agreements have been signed (Corpocam and Asocasan -Tatama-; Amatea -Farallones-; Corpohabitats -Munchique- and Colombian Association of Aquaculture -Orquideas-) for the implementation of activities in 4 National Parks Natural (PNN) participating on the project to improve their sustainable management. Monitoring and control activities have been held in 37,811 ha of Tatamá Park and 10,000 ha in Farallones National Park.
Reports of field patroling and technical concepts of control and surveillance activities in the national parks were developed (Tatamá and Farallones)

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Prevention of emissions (tCO2-e) due to rainforest deforestation

actual.comment: An agreement with Cocomacia was formulated in order to perform a preliminary analysis of technical, economic, social and institutional feasibility of REDD + projects in the priority areas of the project. Under the agreement secondary information for socio-environmental characterization of communities that have shown interest in REDD + projects will be collected, the lessons learned from REDD + processes implemented or being implemented in the Chocó will be systematized; The social, technical and economic viability of at least 10 potential communities to implement REDD + projects is going to be preliminarily analyzed.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Avoided deforestation (ha) at the end of project

actual.comment: Avoided deforestation will be reported through REDD + projects. An agreement with Cocomacia was formulated in order to perform a preliminary analysis of technical, economic, social and institutional feasibility of REDD + projects in the priority areas of the project. Under the agreement secondary information for socio-environmental characterization of communities that have shown interest in REDD + projects will be collected, the lessons learned from REDD + processes implemented or being implemented in the Chocó will be systematized; The social, technical and economic viability of at least 10 potential communities to implement REDD + projects is going to be preliminarily analyzed.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of initiatives for sustainable use of biodiversity resources being marketed

target.comment: Two (2) non-timber products, Naidi (Euterpe oleracea) and Jagua (American Genipa)

actual.comment:
It was made an evaluation of the productive chains of Naidi and Jagua, finding that they are currently limited conditions for the development of these productive chains in the project areas (obtaining resource use licences and rupture of relations between suppliers and retailers) .
Considering the above, an assessment of the problem is being conducted to determine ways to continue and an analysis is going on to understand the current situation in the region with respect to the marketing of non-timber forest products (NTFP) and also the identification of key actors who have been involved in the processes among which are: private actors (Ecoflora and Espavé, Bioinnova Corporation), public institutions (IIAP, Codechoco, MADS) community stakeholders (Cocomacia and Asocasan) with other projects such as the GEF Nagoya.
Progress is being made in the identification and characterization of productive initiatives that are currently developed from non-timber forest products (NTFP) and has potential for generating income for communities in the Choco region, with emphasis on the areas impacted by mining. This exercise will: a) Identify NTFPs generating income for communities, b) Identify the status of the models, companies, initiatives or proposed business plans or systems implementation for NTFP, c) Identify feasibility studies and supply chains of NTFP being carried out, d) identify and characterize the NTFP harvesting protocols that exist for the Chocó e) To propose an analysis matrix, state models or business plans with variables regarding environmental, social and economic and legal sustainability.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Change in average annual income of members of local communities (including women and men) as a result of the sale of assai palm (Euterpe oleracea) and jagua (American Genipa)

target.comment: Women: X Men: X. The goal will be participatory defined on the first six months of the project

actual.comment:
In the process of updating the management plans, productive activities aimed at improving family income will be included. For this, a baseline will be made for families to be included in these processes.
At the same time a strategy will be designed to include a gender perspective in these activities and thus to ensure equality between men and women. For this, it is important to consider the roles of men and women within their communities and organizations, so that we can empower them and contribute to equitable development of families and communities.
A gender strategy will also be included in the training program, linked with the other components of the project.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce the current trend of dry forest deforestation and desertification processes and ensure the flow of multiple global ecosystem services through biodiversity conservation, sustainable land management, and carbon storage.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Coverage (in hectares) of dry forest and other dry ecosystems in protected areas and/or under conservation agreements.

actual.comment:
A) 30,182.5 ha identified as potential areas for protection and conservation (PAs/CAs) in the following prioritized basins:
- 7,198 ha, Cañas-Ancho River (Dibulla)
- 7,698 ha Garupal River (Valledupar)
- 6,499.5 ha, Arroyo Grande River (San Juan Nepomuceno)
- 2,770 ha, Aipe-Patá River (Aipe-Neiva)
- 3,150 ha Yaví River (Natagaima-Prado)
- 2,867 ha, Dagua River (Dagua, La Cumbre, Restrepo and Vijes)
B) One (1) “letter of intention aimed at consolidating the agreement or declaration of conservation areas and sustainable use of the dry forest ecosystem by referendum", signed on June 16, 2015 by representatives of the community action boards of the municipalities of Aipe and Neiva which belong to the basin of the Aipe and Patá Rivers; these areas of influence of the project cover 9,107 ha and conform a landscape matrix which is essential for the conservation, restauration, rehabilitation and sustainable use and the improvement of the dry forest's ecological connectivity and functionality.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of key species per biological group (birds, plants and ants) in permanent observation plots in prioritized areas.

baseline.comment:
Caribbean region:
- Birds: 6
- Flora: 8 (trees)
- Ants: 2
- Region of the Inter-Andean Valley of the Magdalena River:
- Birds: 3
- Flora: 5 (trees)
- Ants: 2.
The species will be selected based on species' lists included in Table 12 of this project document.

target.comment:
Caribbean region:
- Birds: 6
- Flora: 8 (trees)
- Ants: 2
- Region of the Inter-Andean Valley of the Magdalena River:
- Birds: 3
- Flora: 5 (trees)
- Ants: 2

actual.comment:
A biological classification (start point) of bird and plant groups: 1) Prioritized basins in the Caribbean region: Birdlife: A) The Arroyo Grande basin: reported a rich variety of 152 bird species, 10 endemic species and 31 vulnerable species.
B) The Cañas-Ancho basin: reported a rich variety of 119 bird species, 6 endemic species and 21 vulnerable species.
C) The Garupal-Diluvio basin: reported a rich variety of 98 bird species, 6 endemic species and 21 vulnerable species.
Vegetation:
D) The Arroyo Grande basin reported a rich variety of 222 plant species.
E) The Cañas-Ancho basin reported a rich variety of 93 plant species - F) Garupal-Diluvio basin reported a rich variety of 40 plant species.
2) Prioritized basins in the Andean and Pacific regions:
Birdlife:
G) The Aipe basin reported a rich variety of 82 bird species, 5 of which fall into some degree of endemicity and 15 bird species classified as vulnerable.
H) The Dagua basin reported a rich variety of 105 bird species, 6 of which fall into some degree of endemicity and 16 bird species classified as vulnerable.
I) The Yaví basin reported a rich variety of 97 bird species, 6 of which fall into some degree of endemicity and 9 bird species classified as vulnerable.- Vegetation:
J) The Aipe basin reported a rich variety of 160 plant species, 21 of which fall into some degree of threat.
K) The Dagua basin reported a rich variety of 92 plant species, 19 of which fall into some degree of threat.
L) The Yaví basin reported a rich variety of 111 plant species, 15 of which fall into some degree of threat.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: “Carbon units not released (as a global benefit) by the end of the project”.

actual.comment: Carbon units are being recalculated with technical support from the IDEAM (Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Environmental Studies), based on the dry forest cartography mapped by this institute in 2013 and the corresponding calculation methodology. According to this calculation, the goal of 93,700 tCO2 is susceptible to changes which will be promptly reported once the information is delivered by the IDEAM. Additionally, the project held consultations with the Ministry of the Environment and Sustainable Development and the IDEAM regarding the indicator proposed by the project: Identified carbon units with capacity of commercialization in the carbon market as of the end of the project. In this regard, the recommendation is not to address the commercialization in the voluntary carbon market but to link this indicator and its goal to the national priorities. In this sense, it is expected that the indicator will be modified as follows: Carbon units not released (as a global benefit) by the end of the project.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened implementation of the regulatory and land use planning framework facilitates the reduction of dry ecosystem deforestation and desertification processes.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of local plans that incorporate strategies of conservation of biodiversity, sustainable forest management and sustainable land management.

baseline.comment: Regional planning tools (land use plan and/or municipal development plan and/or four-year action plans of the Autonomous Regional Corporations (CARs) and/or the environmental determinants of the CARs: 0

target.comment: Planning tools (land use plan and/or municipal development plan and/or CAR four-year action plans and/or CAR environmental determinants: 12

actual.comment:
Progress achieved in the incorporation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM) conservation strategies into planning relates to processes of change of land use plans (second generation) that are currently conducted by the municipalities as well as changes on regulatory tools related to environmental guidelines and determinants for land use currently conducted by the CARs:
A) One (1) document of diagnosis and technical assessment of the environmental component for the 6 municipalities in the work area: Natagaima, Aipe, Dagua (Andean region) and Dibulla, San Juan Nepomuceno and Valledupar (Caribbean region).
B) 3 technical documents prepared with recommendations (municipalities of Dibulla, Natagaima and Valledupar) for the incorporation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM) in the land use plans.
C) 2 technical documents sent to the municipalities of Dibulla, Natagaima and Valledupar with recommendations for the incorporation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM) in the land use plans.
D) 6 technical meetings with the municipalities of: Natagaima, Dibulla, Valledupar, San Juan Nepomuceno, Aipe, Dagua to include dry forest and sustainable land management in land use plans.
E) One (1) land use plan (Valledupar) incorporates protection of primary forests (including dry forest) and high stubbles to land use. Valledupar's Municipal Council Agreement No. 011 from 5-June-2015
F) 4 technical meetings conducted to review environmental determinants (Cortolima, Corpoguajira, Corpocesar, CAM).
G) 4 documents prepared and sent with recommendations of incorporation of dry forest in environmental guidelines and determinants for land use: Cortolima, Corpoguajira, Corpocesar and Cardique.
H) 2 resolutions from the CARs adopting dry forest as an environmental guideline for land use: Cortolima (Resolution 560 of 20-March-2015) and Corpocesar (Resolution 0674 of 18-June-2015)
I) Elaboration of chapter 2.4: Sustainable Development and Environmental Management? in the UNDP-DNP(National Planning Department) paper called "Orientaciones para la construcción de programas de gobierno: Guía para candidatos, candidatas y ciudadanía - Elecciones de autoridades locales 2015” [Guidelines for the construction of government programs: A guide for candidates and citizens - Local Authority Election 2015]. Due to changes in the administration, the development of the second generation of the land use plan progresses very slowly; this is the reason why the project will have an influence upon other planning tools such as the CAR four-year action plans and the CAR environmental determinants on land use. In this sense, it is expected that the goal will be modified as follows: 12 planning tools (land use plan and/or municipal development plan and/or CAR four-year action plans of and/or CAR environmental determinants include strategies of conservation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of professional and technical staff members of CARs, MADS, IDEAM and local and regional authorities designing and implementing strategies of SLM, REDD+ and biodiversity conservation.

baseline.comment:
IDEAM: 5
MADS (Ministry of the Environment and Sustainable Development): 3
CARs: 37
Municipal mayor's offices: 6
Departmental governments: 13

target.comment:
IDEAM: 10
MADS: 10
CARs: 87
Municipal mayor's offices: 18
Departmental governments: 20

actual.comment:
1) The following actions have been undertaken to implement GIS tools to guide local and regional authorities in planning processes and environmental follow-up and monitoring:
A) 6 computers with installed ArcGis license delivered to the CARs as part of the strengthening of Geographic Information Systems to guide processes of planning and for the follow-up and monitoring of biodiversity, sustainable forest management and sustainable land management (REDD+).
2) The following training has been conducted related to education programs for government officers and social organizations:
A) 6 training/induction meetings with CAR officers on the handling of GIS tools and computers delivered by the project. A total of 14 officers trained, 10 men and 4 women.
B) 6 training workshops on addressing methodologies for the declaration of protected areas and/or conservation agreements and the implementation of landscape management tools. A total of 127 officers trained, 74 men and 53 women.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Changes in the institutional capacity of CARs based on the UNDP sheet of assessment of capacity development:
a. Participation capacity
b. Capacity of generation, access and usage of information and knowledge.
c. Capacity of development of strategies, policies and legislation.
d. Capacity of management and implementation.
e. Capacity of monitoring and evaluation.

actual.comment:
The following actions have been conducted as part of the CAR capacity assessment:
A) 6 UNDP capacity assessment forms sent to CARs to be completed: CVC, CAM, Corpoguajira, Cortolima, Corpocesar and Cardique.
B) 5 capacity assessment forms filled by CARs and reviewed: CVC, CAM, Corpoguajira, Corpocesar and Cardique.
Results show that the CARs require substantial strengthening in terms of the handling of GIS tools for environmental planning and for environmental follow-up and monitoring within their jurisdictions. Similarly, the CARs continue to show capacity weaknesses in terms of generation, access and use of information.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of local plans that incorporate strategies of conservation of biodiversity, sustainable forest management and sustainable land management.

baseline.comment:
Land use plans: 0
Municipal development plans: 0

target.comment: 12 planning tools (land use plan and/or municipal development plan and/or CAR four-year action plans of and/or CAR environmental guidelines and determinants include strategies of conservation of biodiversity, sustainable forest management and sustainable land management.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Delivery of multiple global environmental benefits through the declaration of PAs and/or conservation agreements, REDD+ practices, and SLM activities that strengthen the conservation and sustainable use of dry ecosystems.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of protected areas and/or conservation agreements that include dry forest at the national level.

baseline.comment:
PAs: 25
Conservation agreements: 0*
* It will be confirmed during the project's first year of implementation.

target.comment:
PAs: Up to 37
Conservation agreements: up to 12

actual.comment:
The following actions refer to the progress made on defining 12 protected areas and/or conservation agreements:
A) One (1) “letter of intention aimed at consolidating the agreement or declaration of conservation areas and sustainable use of the dry forest ecosystem by referendum", signed on June 16, 2015 by representatives of the community action boards of the municipalities of Aipe and Neiva which belong to the basin of the Aipe and Patá Rivers; these areas of influence of the project cover 9,107 ha and conform a landscape matrix which is essential for the conservation, restauration, rehabilitation and sustainable use and the improvement of the dry forest's ecological connectivity and functionality.
B) 30,182.5 ha identified as potential areas for protection and conservation (PAs/CAs) through the following prioritized basins:
- 7,198 ha, Cañas-Ancho River (Dibulla)
- 7,698 ha Garupal River (Valledupar)
- 6,499.5 ha, Arroyo Grande River (San Juan Nepomuceno)
- 2,770 ha, Aipe-Patá River (Aipe-Neiva)
- 3,150 ha Yaví River (Natagaima-Prado)
- 2,867 ha, Dagua River (Dagua, La Cumbre, Restrepo and Vijes).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Management effectiveness of two protected areas with dry forest measured through the METT score sheet based on the effectiveness analysis used at the national level.

baseline.comment:
Integrated Management District (DMI) of Atuncela: 49.02%
Land Conservation District (DCS) of Río Grande*: 0
*It will be confirmed in the project's mid-term evaluation.

target.comment:
Integrated Management District of Atuncela: 59.02%
Land Conservation District (DCS) of Río Grande*: 10%
*Increases by 10% according to baseline.

actual.comment: The project developed a prioritization exercise and agreed that it is not cost-effective to work in Ceibotes and Besotes because these two protected areas are outside of the prioritized areas of the project; therefore actions to be conducted will not benefit these two areas. Thus, the work will be done in the Land Conservation District of Río Grande, located in the basin of the Dagua River. Therefore, the following change to the indicator is proposed: Change in management effectiveness of two dry forest protected areas, measured through the METT score sheet, based on management effectiveness assessments which are used at the regional level. The goal will focus on the protected areas: The Integrated Management District of Atuncela and the Land Conservation District of Río Grande, both of the areas located in the basin of the Dagua River. Based on the above, a form was sent to CVC, regarding the two protected areas: The Integrated Management District of Atuncela and the Land Conservation District of Río Grande. Through this form, the baseline for the Atuncela DMI will be confirmed and the baseline for the Río Grande DCS will be established.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Change in the financial capacity for the management of the protected areas with dry forest as stated through the total average score obtained in the Financial Sustainability Sheet (tracking tool).

baseline.comment:
Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks: 26.32%
Business planning and cost-effective management tools: 36%
Income generation tools for protected areas: 25%
Total: 28.44%
Note: the baseline and the goal will be confirmed during the project's first year of implementation.

target.comment:
Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks: 36.32%
Business planning and tools for cost-effective management: 46%
Income generation tools for protected areas: 35%
Total: 38.44%

actual.comment:
The project developed a prioritization exercise and agreed that it is not cost-effective to work in Ceibotes and Besotes because these two protected areas are outside of the prioritized areas of the project; therefore actions to be conducted will not benefit these two areas. Thus, the work will be done in the Land Conservation District of Río Grande, located in the basin of the Dagua River.
To date, a form has been sent to CVC for the corresponding two protected areas: The Integrated Management District of Atuncela and the Land Conservation District of Río Grande. Through this form, the baseline for the Atuncela DMI will be confirmed and the baseline for the Río Grande DCS will be established..

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Area (in hectares) of dry forest under implementation of REDD+ activities, by the end of the project.

actual.comment: With technical support from the IDEAM, dry forest hectares affected by sustainable forest management activities (REDD+) are being recalculated. This depends of the carbon units content, based on the dry forest cartography created by this institute in 2013. According to this calculation, the amount of hectares is susceptible to changes, which will be promptly reported once the information is delivered by the IDEAM.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Reduction of net emissions (tCO2-e) (aerial biomass) due to avoided deforestation, by the end of the project.

target.comment: Garupal River Basin: 50,587 tCO2-e*. Dagua River Basin: 43,113 tCO2-e* : These figures will be verified during the first year of the project.

actual.comment: With technical support from the IDEAM, the net emission reduction (tCO2-e) (aerial biomass) due to avoided deforestation, by the end of the project, is being recalculated based on dry forest cartography created by this institute in 2013. According to this calculation, the net emission reduction is susceptible to changes which will be promptly reported once the information is delivered by the IDEAM.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Reduction of net emissions (tCO2-e) (underground biomass) due to avoided deforestation, by the end of the project.

target.comment: Garupal River Basin: X* tCO2-e - Dagua River Basin: X* tCO2-e * It will be estimated during the project's first year of implementation

actual.comment: With technical support from the IDEAM, the net emission reduction (tCO2-e) (aerial biomass) due to avoided deforestation, by the end of the project, is being recalculated based on dry forest cartography created by this institute in 2013. According to this calculation, the net emission reduction is susceptible to changes which will be promptly reported once the information is delivered by the IDEAM.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Avoided deforestation in hectares, by the end of the project.

target.comment: Garupal River Basin: 522.65 ha, Dagua River Basin: 445.42 ha

actual.comment: With technical support from the IDEAM, the avoided deforestation by the end of the project is being recalculated, based on dry forest cartography produced by the institute in 2013. According to this calculation, the avoided deforestation is susceptible to changes which will be promptly reported once the information is delivered by the IDEAM.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Water flow (m3/sec) by the Hydrological Response Units (HRU) in each prioritized basin.

baseline.comment:
Cañas River: 12 m3/sec (dry season)
- Garupal River: 0.53 m3/sec (dry season)
- Arroyo Grande River: Without information*
- Aipe River: 3.1 m3/sec (dry season)
- Yaví River: 2.42 m3/sec (dry season).
Dagua River: 12.9 m3/seg (upper waters, dry season)
* It will be estimated during the first year of the project's implementation
- Note: Sources of information are included as a footnote on page 35.

target.comment:
Cañas River: 12 m3/sec (dry season)
- Garupal River: 0.53 m3/sec (dry season)
- Arroyo Grande River: Without information*
- Aipe River: 3.1 m3/sec (dry season)
- Yaví River: 2.42 m3/sec (dry season).
Dagua River: 12.9 m3/seg (upper waters, dry season)
* It will be estimated during the first year of the project's implementation

actual.comment: This goal will be reported for the second half-year of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Soil loss: Sediment (Total suspended solids – TSS) provided by the Hydrological Response Units in each prioritized basin.

baseline.comment:
Cañas River: 222 t/ha/year
- Garupal River: Without information*
- Arroyo Grande River: Without information*
- Aipe River: 10.5 t/ha/year
- Yaví River: 100 t/ha/year
- Dagua River: 220 t/ha/year
*It will be estimated during the project's first year of implementation
- Note: The baseline information was obtained from the National Water Study (ENA, in its Spanish acronym) (IDEAM, 2010).

target.comment:
Cañas River: 176.6 t/ha/year
- Garupal River: Without information*
- Arroyo Grande River: Without information*
- Aipe River: 8.4 t/ha/year - Yaví River: 80 t/ha/year
- Dagua River: 160 t/ha/year.
* It will be estimated during the project's first year of implementation

actual.comment: This goal will be reported for the second half-year of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Area (in hectares) of rehabilitated dry forest.

actual.comment:
The following actions have been undertaken regarding implementation of landscape management tools, to contribute to the maintenance of water flows and reduction of degradation and desertification.
A) Identification of areas of conservation value for the design and establishment of landscape management tools (HMP, in its Spanish acronym), in tropical dry forest (bs-T, in its Spanish acronyn) for the prioritized basins, three in the Caribbean region and three in the Andean region. The areas with conservation value were established not only according to indicator biological groups but based on the ecosystem service offer. 6 maps were created (one per basin), identifying areas of conservation value.
B) Design of a conservation corridor and process of socioeconomic characterization of lands with local actors of the prioritized basins in the Caribbean region.
C) Monitoring protocols for indicators of ecosystem functions (water and soil) in 6 basins prioritized for the implementation of landscape management tools.
D) Methodology for the design and conciliation procedure (negotiation) of a model for the process of participative plot planning model for the design of landscape management tools.
E) Agreements were reached with Corpoguajira and Los Colorados Flora and Fauna Sanctuary to set up plant nurseries. In this respect, a technical proposal was prepared for the production of vegetal material to set up the landscape management tools.
